The bears had gotten into the dog food left out on the porch and the grill after they had cooked some meat on it.  The last sighting they had of it was approximately a week ago.  I advised them to keep the dog food in at night and to put ammonia  jars on the porch or near the grill after cooking.  I also gave her some bean bags rounds and advised her only to use them if the sow is at a safe distance.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set
Comments:
Jamie with USFS  reported some incidents she had discovered around July 2. A couple at site 10 had an issue with a bear being close, built a "boma" fence around their camp, and still had a black bear take coffee from inside their fence. Jamie had spoken with campers at sites 16 and 17, both had seen the bear and it was close but did not get any food. These incidents happened around Thurs/Friday (July 2/3). I found a camp at site 19 that was wrecked, tent had been ripped open and food, trash and dog food was all over the place. Occupant was not there. Campers at site 21 said camp at 19 had been fine on Friday evening, and they found it trashed on Sat. Campers at 21 also showed me a video of a large black bear near their camp.

Set trap at site 18 on July 5. Spoke with site 19 occupant on July 6 and discussed keeping food secured in camp. No issues reported by other campers, pulled trap July 6.

NO RESPONSE NEEDED.

Bear found in tree in front yard by Ned PD. Tree in busy area and close to a social trail that is commonly used. WL 128 tased twice, bear last seen running east on 4th Street.

Bear has been an issue all summer long but RP hasn't called in until now.  Bear has RED 8241 ear tags.  Bear is not aggressive at all but came up behind RP when he was grilling but he was able to scare it off.  RP says bear is small about lab size.  RP concerned since he has a 2 and 4 year old and doesn't want the bear to come upon the kids.  RP does not have any bird feeders, dog food etc, just the grill.  I told him to power wash or clean up the grill as much as he possibly could and then spray either a bleach solution or ammonia solution on the grill itself and the ground around it.  Party is very willing to do that.  He's just concerned about when he's grilling again what he should do.  He would like a call back.  KH-HSS
Spoke with RP. He advised bear does not run away when the drive up to it. I asked if he walked up to and he advised he did and it ran away. RP is building a house up there and present on weekends only. Asked him to call this weekend and I would provide bean bag rounds to him. WL 482

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set , Educational Materials
Comments:
Bear tried to get into house repeatedly several days and gained entry once.
Trap removed 7/20

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set
Comments: Bear broke into three occupied cabins. Ongoing issue

Small cub that has been reported in the area for the last week ended up being run up the pole on a porch at the anta grande elk farm. DWM Gallegos attempted to catch using catch pole, but was unsuccessful. Cub ran to a large cottonwood tree, so he decided to leave him for now.
Bear has been hanging around for a few day. On and off porch ( just unwelcome) rubber buck was provide
Bear was hit on I-25 near the northgate exit.

On 06/24/2020 Wildlife 261 received an email from his AWM stating that the Forest Service in the area received  a bear incident call and the RP's information was listed. WL 261 contacted the RP. The RP stated that on that earlier the day of the incident they had seen a bear in the area, but after it noticed the party it walked off. Later that night at around dusk, 8 individuals and 7 dogs were sitting in a circle conversing. At this time the RP heard her dog start to growl and head twigs breaking near her tent where her child was sleeping. The RP at this point rushed over to the tent where she saw a bear standing on its hind legs with a paw on the top of the tent. The RP immediately began screaming and chased the bear away. The bear did rip a portion of the tent, but the child was not injured. WL 261 asked the RP if there were any attractants in the tent or anything with any strong odor. The RP stated that there was not because they had read the signs about the area being bear country when they entered the area, but she thought that maybe the sweet odor of the laundry detergent could have something to do with it. WL 261 gave the party some information on camping in bear country and gave her some advice for a backpacking trip she was going to be taking with her family in the near future. He also stressed the importance of contacting CPW as soon as possible after an event like this, so that CPW could employ best wildlife practices. The RP stated that she would, but they didn't want anything to happen to the bear so they were reluctant to say anything. 

After contact with the RP WL 261 looked at the email string where he was informed of the incident and discovered that the original email was created on 06/15/2020, but by the time it made its way through the Forest Service ranks and forwarded to WL 261 it was 06/24/2020.
Attempt to sit out to shoot bear upon its return. RP said they could hear hit “popping it’s teeth” in the bushes as they repaired  the bee hives.     Hounds unavailable.

RP heard noise outside door and went out.  Saw bear in driveway, about 30 feet away.   Yelled at bear, and returned to house to get gun.  Went back outside, yelled again at bear.  Bear growled, and started approaching him.  Bear got to within 15 feet with him yelling at if.  He shot bear with .45 pistol, bear ran up nearby tree.  RP called dispatch,  and myself and a deputy responded.  Bear was in tree when I arrived,  and fell out a short time later.  I walked up to it and put down wounded bear.  Donated meat to local family.   Seal # 37187

Complaint Type: Food Source Property Damage , Sighting , Aggressive Behavior
Comments:
RP called to report that there had been some bear activity in the jelly stone campground. Said that the bear had gotten into a roll-off trash container that was there from construction. The bear had also gotten into some trash that someone at a campground had left out. WL544 asked if there was any way to clean up the trash going into the roll off and make sure that it was only construction materials. RP said the roll-off was being removed. WL544 suggested that jelly stone continues to push education materials to incoming campers and to keep WL544 updated if events continue. WL544 also suggested hazing the bears with loud noise and making sure that they were not welcome in the campground. RP said that they would continue to do that and that the bears had not really been though the campground yet just on the outskirts of the west side. WL544 asked how many bears were around and RP said that he believed there were three different bears. 
END

On August 20th, 2020 Eric called to report that he was having issues with the bears again. They are getting around the bear-proof dumpsters and the enclosures.

On September 1st Jellystone notifies WL544 that they had chased a bear out of one of their dumpsters. The RP stated that the bear then climbed a tree and was sitting in the tree making huffing noises. This occurred at 1:37 am.  WL544 advises that they should leave the bear alone now that they hazed it and give it the chance to move on. An hour later the park staff was escorting someone to their campsite. RP noticed that the bear had left the tree and was now back on the ground. RP stated the bear followed the golf cart at a slight jog for a little bit. RP also noticed the bear was huffing. RP said that they felt the bear was irritated because they kept hazing it away.

On September 2nd at around 10 pm WL544 observed a bear on a dumpster. WL544 shot this bear with a taser to haze it away from the dumpster. The bear took a full 5-second ride and then ran off into the woods. WL544 saw the bear running down the fence line. WL544 then grabbed his paintball gun to Mark the bear. The bear then climbed a ponderosa pine tree. WL544 shot the bear with permeant orange paint on its hind end while one of the park rangers held a flashlight on it.

On September 3rd at 3 pm one of the rangers for the larkspur campground called to report an incident with a bear. The ranger stated that he was coming down the hill towards the activities dumpster and saw 3-4 bags of trash on the ground . The ranger stopped to pick the trash up. The ranger heard a huffing noise. the ranger then saw a large black bear with what was described as a gingerish marking behind the left ear. Ranger also stated the bear was marked with orange on the rear. The ranger then stated that he got back in the golf cart and drove away. The ranger stated that he felt something brush the back of his leg. The ranger was not sure what brushed the back of his leg. The ranger went back to the area later on at 3:45 and the bear was no longer in the area. WL544 took a statment for the ranger. WL544 placed signs in the area that this occurred letting people know there is bear activity in the area. WL544 also stayed out overnight to try and observe the specific bears behavior. WL544 did not observe that specific bear but did observe a different bear that ran when WL544 approached. Jellystone campground is in the process of educating campers and switching out all non bear proof dumpster to ones sufficient to keep bears out. Rangers are also currently going around and telling campers that they need to lock up food sources at night. 
END

Complaint Type: Food Source Property Damage , Non-Food Property Damage , Sighting
Comments: RP stated large black sow with 3 cubs has visited residence three nights in a row. Once pushed garage door in to get trash, another time wandered around front door and stood against door in daylight hours (8pm), then chewed bottom panel of garage door another night. RP also has chickens that are in well-enclosed coop. Likely same Bear and cubs that gained access to a garage at a nearby residence in the previous week. Two traps set on 7/20. Traps pulled on 7/23.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set , Euthanized
Comments:
This bear was trapped and relocated from the Red Feather Lakes area on Sept 1, 2019..
On June 11, 2020, RP reported having a locked building broken into and a freezer opened by a bear. Also, evidence showed the bear tried to get into an occupied house nearby.
CPW set a live trap on site and trapped the bear the next morning. The bear was previously ear tagged and was thus euthanized.

RP called and said she wanted a bear trapped and moved because it was getting her bird feeders.  Krall told RP that bears were not relocated due to bird feeders and asked her to stop feeding birds and put bird feeders away.  Krall gave RP rubber slugs for the bear if it returned.  RP agreed to quit feeding birds.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials
Comments: RP was concerned a bear had visited her property and tried to get in with her goats because the electric fence around the pen was not tight anymore.  I looked around and found bear poop on the property so it is  plausible that a bear tried to enter the goat pen.  The electric fence most likely did it’s job and the bear left without getting in.  There are parts of the pen and chicken coop that are not electrified and I recommended that they electrify that section.  There was a pallet of grower feed outside the electric fence and I recommended that be stored inside the electrified area.  Gave her a Living with Bears pamphlet for further recommendations on how to minimize conflicts with bears.  Asked RP to call if she had anymore problems with the bear.  I performed the site inspection on 7-28-2020 but the app on my cell phone was not working hence the reason for entering the information a day later.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials , Euthanized
Staff Assigned: Matt.Yamashita@state.co.us; Devin.Duval@state.co.us; Brian.Wodrich@state.co.us; Darren.Chacon@state.co.us; Peter.Boyatt@state.co.us; michael.sirochman@state.co.us
Comments:
The homeowner, Marvin Robinowitz went out the back door at approximately 0745 hours on 10/22/20 to let his dog out.  At that time a "large, brown bear" ran at him and swiped him with her paw, hitting him in his right arm, causing several cuts.  Robinowitz separated himself from the bear and then she charged a second time but did not make contact with him.  Robinowitz was able to safely get himself and his dog inside the house then had his wife drive him to the hospital where he received a couple stiches and was released.  The bear was found in the tree outside Robinowitz's back door with two cubs.  The sow was euthanized and the two cubs were relocated to a rehab center.
For more detailed report, see "Bear Attack Edwards_Wodrich ROI".

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials
Comments:
2 bears have been visiting the property. RP attempted to secure the shed with locks and the bears ripped both doors off. He does have a koi pond and koi food in the shred.  No other food source in the yard.  They have killed 4 fish so far.  One of the bears came into the yard with homeowner and worker present, went past them and into the shed. Not showing fear of humans. Reported 2 weeks ago and the bears have been back frequently.  Comes up on the back porch. Requesting site visit. 

1. Sub Adult - BLACK - has shoulder damage, unable to climb trees, poor body condition. 
2. Adult - BLACK


Watson provided 2 unwelcome Matt's for the shed, I recommended putting electric fence around the koi ponds but home owner stated "im not going to waste my time on something I know won't work" I told RP to keep in touch if bears continue to come back

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials
Comments: Bear got into trash can and bird feeders on back porch. Educated landowner. Got property cleaned

Bear was getting into chicken coop. RP tried to scare off the bear. By yelling and shooting a pistol into the ground. It would not leave so he shot at it with a .22 and it left for a few min. It returned and got into his dog run with is dog. He got a rifle out of house a killed the bear.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set , Educational Materials , Euthanized
Comments:
PCBR: PLZ CALL /BEAR HAS BEEN HANGING AROUND FOR ABOUT THREE DAYS - DOGS CHASED HIM UP
A TREE -
HAS 2 RED TAGS / HAS ALSO BEEN IN THE NEIGHBORS YARD WHILE THE KIDS ARE IN THE

6/6 update: Trap reset and re-baited. Seems as if either trap malfunctioned or the bear has figured out how to flip the treadle. Homeowners placed a camera nearby to confirm, may need to try a culvert trap. Donuts/baked goods worked to get the bear in the trap.

6/9 
Bear caught and euthanized

customer contacted police department 05/16/2020, was told by our office that not to worry about it.  Received a call from our office from a female around 1 hour after she called PD.  She is very upset.   Since then a bear was seen on May 29th by her neighbor that had to scare it away.  The woman is very upset and needs a call back to reassure her.  She is stressing out since she lives on 4 acres and has 2 special needs boys that do not understand the danger of a mountain lion and or a bear.  She has a small grand child and daughter as well.  Her neighbors said they would shoot the animals, she wants them relocated.  I did not confirm that was an option.

Edit by Richman:  I was bit by their large German Shepard. Be careful approaching residence.  Neither 2nd hand “sighting” report of bears or lions could be verified.  No indication of either species calls into question the credibility of the reports.
RP stated that the bear was going from trash can to trash can.  Cars going by where honking .  Bear did not move away or run off. 492 delivered rubber buckshot.

CSP informed 442 that the RP had heard gunshots and shortly after a bear had limped through his yard. 442 went to the RPs address and talked with him about seeing the bear and it's behavior. 442 could not find any traces of blood or any indication that a bear had been shot in the area. 442 then went to the neighbors house at 621 Elk Run Rd. and learned that the owner, Garrett (unknown last name) had a bear getting into his garbage and had shot several rounds with his rifle to scare it away. 442 inspected the surrounding area, found empty .223 shells but no traces of blood or any indication a bear had been shot in the area. 442 supplied Garrett with rubber buckshot and instructed him to use that instead of a rifle. 442 talked with both landowners about securing trash, removing bird feeders, etc. to prevent the bear from viewing there residences as a source of food.

Rp saw bear walking through neighborhood. Had noticeable limp and was not using rear right leg. Rp sent video and bear looks very healthy and large. Probably a boar. Went to site and bear had left area using a culvert to cross under I-70. Lots of older bear tracks in area.

DNPD advised of bear in trash - same bear as in previous reports. Due to being relatively early in the evening, quite a few people were out.causing potential issues. DWM Gallegos responded, and with the assistance of DNPD and RGSO Deputy, pushed the bear back toward the river. The bear was hazed with rubber buckshot.

RP reported a very large, inured bear in their yard over night.  465 visited home, owners showed video of a large limping bear in the yard that morning at about midnight.  Bear is still mobile, so 465 advised to keep an eye on the bear and attempt to haze it away.  The owners also advised of a sow and 2 cubs hanging in the area.  Seems like bears are utilizing berries along the river.   Fyi.
APHIS dogs alerted to the presence of bear after failed attempts in a different location.  Called landowner, got permission to remove.
Large bear eating crab apples. RP nervous because it would not willingly leave with her dog barking at it.

RP came back from vacation and found a dead sow and  one cub in her backyard.  

WL 288 and 287 went to the address to investigate. The sow is the injured sow with  two cubs that has been seen in the area throughout summer. WL 287 believes there in not an abandoned cub, as  a cub was found shot  in a near by neighborhood on 09/24/2020. This cub was distinct due to an ear missing.  The RP had multiple videos of the family playing in her pond. Videos show the sow with two cubs, one having a missing ear. 

 Both the sow and the cub were facing uphill and had blood coming from their noses.  They had most likely died sometime the previous day.  WL 287 and 288 looked for trauma and could not find any.  The metal detector was unable to locate  metal. 

The RP had mouse bait in 4 mouse trap containers, \.  The bears did not get into these. 

Both bears are being sent to the health lab.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Trap Set , Educational Materials
Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials , Pyrotechnics
Comments: Mark was told to keep windows closed and locked when not needed for air ventilation. Mark observed bear in window but did not know if bear was actually in house. Mark was given non-lethal shotgun ammunition for hazing.

Complaint Type: Non-Food Property Damage , Sighting , Aggressive Behavior
Comments: RP stated she noticed a bear going under her deck. It ripped wood off. She put wood back to see if the bear would come back. She called a deck repair company to look at it today and the bear was down there and it growled at them. Bear was under deck at time of call/ Called WL 488 immediately. -SC HSS WL 488 arrived and bear was still under deck. Popped jaw and low growled when shining flashlight on bear. Was unable to taser bear due to its position but pepper sprayed it. Shortly after bear came out and left area. Siding below deck was fairly destroyed by bear. Dumped bleach and tried to fill holes with lumber until deck can be repaired. Advised rp to clear area of any scent lures and to use sturdy material for siding.
Randy Leonard round 2 dead lambs and 1 ewe killed by bear.  Wildlife Services called to remove bear.  Wildlife services killed 175 lb sow off sheep carcasses night of 7/2.

RP reported a brown colored bear in his garden.  Was worried about his chickens and said he would drop the bear if it got in the chickens.  Krall told RP to electrify chickens and offered to put up temporary electric fence until RP could get their own.  RP told Krall he would put up his own fence.

Bear is 200+ and very black with an injured Right front leg.  Bear ran from the intersection of Hwy 34 and 40 from the North to the South towards the railroad track into the willows.   RP did not need contacted but possible site inspection to check on bear was suggested.  KH _ HSS

RP shot yearling boar in his backyard.  The bear ate one of his free ranging chickens.  RP walked out of his house and shot the bear with an AR15 at approximately 4 yards.  RP said that he did not think he would be able to chase the bear away and he is passionate about his chickens.  After Officer Holder placed the yearling bear in the back of his truck the RP asked Officer Holder if he could see the bear.  Officer Holder asked him why he wanted to see the bear.  The RP said that he wanted see the wound that the ammo he used made.  He said he used frangible ammo to shoot it.  Officer Holder told him "no".  Officer Holder skinned the bear and retained the hide, head, and claws for sale at public auction.

The morning of 06/11/2020 WL 290 got a call from cory code enforcement that there was a bear attack the previous night.  WL 287 called the RP and code enforcement for more information.

RP was walking his dog down Shoshone Place . The dog was off leash. The RP noticed a bear on a trashcan and continued walking. The bear charged and his dog attacked the bears stomach and then the bear attacked the dog.  The RP then saw 2-3 cubs with the sow. They are this years cubs and the RP believes all the bears were black in color. There bear did NOT attack the human.  

WL 287 did a site inspection and there is no place to set a trap in the area.  Will continue to monitor the situation.

Complaint Type: Food Source Property Damage , Non-Food Property Damage , Sighting , Aggressive Behavior

Comments: Sow and two cubs got in RPs trash that was sitting out not secured

Complaint Type: Food Source Property Damage , Non-Food Property Damage

Comments: Colleen, Blanche’s daughter called to report a bear had tried to enter home twice, once on July 10 through kitchen window and grabbed a bag of bagels, and on July 13 tried to enter through dining room window. Blanche scared bear off before it entered house. 326 set trap on site July 13 through July 19. Camera on trap showed no bear activity. Trap pulled 7/19. Advised Colleen of unwelcome mats and provided literature on how to make one. Nothing further.

Complaint Type: Food Source Property Damage , Non-Food Property Damage , Sighting
Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set
Comments: RP had a bear break in during the night. Bear gained entry through partially opened window. Bear came into kitchen and was rewarded with food left out on the counters. First report of a bear at this location, but resulted in home entry. RP heard the bear and came downstairs, and made enough noise to scare off the animal. ECSO also responded. RP was called back at 3am, message left, and then called again at 6:30am. Bear was roughly described as medium size with brown coloration. Trap set at RP's address on 7/15.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials , Pyrotechnics
Comments:
Bear came in and got a bad or feed out of RP's trailer on two separate occasions.  On one occassion the bear damaged the bottom corner of the RP's white cargo trailer.  The feed was stored inside this trailer.  WL 265 responded and did a site inspection.  RP was adamant that the bear not be trapped when that was offered to her.  I recommended the use of electric fence around the trailer.  Rp said that she and her husband were going to look into that option.  Offered the use of bear unwelcome mats to her.  She said if they didn't purchase the electric  fence she would like to use them. 
 Gave her rubber shot to haze the bear and a living with bears pamphlet for further information on how to minimize conflicts with bears.    RP has my card and I asked her to call me if she has any additional conflicts with the bear.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set

Comments: Bob heard something at his window.  Next morning screen was torn up.  Bob did not know what it was.  Upon a site visit DWM Ortega observed muddy bear paw marks on the window and scratches in a screen consistent with bear claws.  Ortega suggested deter ants Bob could try and to report if bear returned.

WL124: I provided five rounds of rubber buckshot to RP's husband after they observed a bear on the property the evening before and showed little fear of hazing via noise. RP also stated a neighbor's chickens were killed by a bear recently. Provided advice.
Bear cub repeatedly approaches and follows FS crew as they are working. No sow in seen in area. RP concerned the cub may be abandoned. RP advised them to leave cub alone and keep their distance.
Bear has been seen on the property on 6/10, 6/19 and 6/25.  No aggressive behavior or break-in attempts yet.  RP was given rubber buckshot and cracker shells for now.

RP manages Highway House, bear keeps getting into "locked, Bear-proof" dumpster. I asked that she call her trash provider and request they replace the dumpster. I will also go by and have a look to see what's going on with the dumpster.

RP reports that there is a small black colored bear in her yard. No damage to any property, and bear, presumably a cub, left the area just before 127 could arrive, utl afterward. RP says that bear was also seen on Saturday (9/5).

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials
Comments: Brian called to report bear in the camp dumpster, which was unlocked. Advised to lock the 4yard dumpster. WL 326 will drop off educational materials.
Bear got into dumpsters, tried getting into campers and tents. Trap set on 6/24. Bear caught and euthanized on 6/26. Same bear a trap was set for on 6/14 and did not catch.

No further response needed
Connie and her husband were outside doing chores when one of their dogs started barking and headed toward the goat pen. The husband followed the dog and then saw a bear eating one of their goats. The dog kept going towards the bear and then the bear started walking towards the dog and husband. Connie called CPW and notified that there was a bear actively eating her goat.  WLO's 549, 548 and 544 were all about 30 minutes out, but headed to the residence to make an attempt to haze the bear. Castle Rock Animal Control arrived and kept the residents inside the house until WLO 549 arrived around 2pm. The bear was no longer at the residence when they arrived and they could not haze the bear. WLO 549 noticed that the backyard had chickens running around  and an apiary that was behind electric fence. Connie told WLO 549 that they have had issues with bears for 3 years and have electrified the fence around their hives and chicken coop. They also had a radio and motion sensor lights around those fences. There was no electric fence around the goat pen and it was at the back of the property. 
The property is covered by oak brush, plum and choke cherry bushes. WLO told Connie that her backyard still has a lot of attractants for bears and that they need to clean up all attractants. The goat that was not eaten was put in the chicken coop and Connie said they will be taking it to their property in Kiowa. WLO let Connie know that they can shoot the bear if it is actively pursuing her livestock or putting human lives in danger. Connie was told to haze the bear with loud noises and was given bear spray.  Connie will notify WLO 549 if bear returns. 
-WLO 549 8/7/2020

Bear cub sighting in Loveland near 8th and Taft.  Becca at 1112 Guard Unit B saw the cub go from her backyard  into a neighbors back yard.  I knocked on some doors and looked in the adjacent back yards and was UTL the cub.  Advise given.
RP said that sow and cub climbed into tree in driveway.  RP and wife left house. Passed on to WL 522- went by residence, bears were gone but numerous bird feeders were seen.

RP went out to irrigate and startled a bear that was near the pump house. The RP ran from the bear and the bear reportedly chased him into his back yard. The RP then got a gun and shot the bear. DWM Smith received a call from the office and investigated the conflict and picked up the dead bear. No further action was taken.

Sow w/ 3 cubs has been coming back to house frequently. Bear keeps going into trash. RP has used ratchet straps to try and keep can closed, also has chained can to tree. RP's trash provider does not offer a bearproof can. Advised RP to buy 3rd party can and transfer trash into it on trash day. Also advised to put multiple ratchet straps. RP is very worried because her kids stay out late and bear walked by camera 5 mins before one came home.

Complaint Type: Food Source Property Damage , Non-Food Property Damage , Sighting

Comments: Neighbor reported a bear in her tree,  but didn't respond to the door. Talked to Ike next door, who said the bear was there last night, and had gotten into trash. Trash has been ongoing, but until they saw the bear, they thought it was raccoons. Advised to secure their trash. -127

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set , Euthanized
Comments: RP called and reported a large bear had been around their cabin for about five days.  Said it got into a 5 gallon bucket of dog food that was left out, it got their bird feeders, into their trash and broke into a shed.  They said it had attempted to get into a hard sided camper several times.  They showed Krall photos of the bear.  Krall told them to secure all attractants and leave nothing out.  Krall contacted the neighboring Lutheran Camp who told him that they had also had the bear get into an empty freezer and an outside gear area.  Krall also received a report from campers in the neighboring Lake Creek campground that the bear got into an empty cooler that had food in it earlier.  All parties said the bear was not aggressive, but it was not afraid either.  Krall set a culvert trap.  The bear would not trap but continued to visit the area regularly.  On 07/14 Krall used houndsman Jon Evert to run the bear with dogs.  The bear was treed and euthanized by Krall.  Meat was donated(cert #D309) and the hide and skull were retained by CPW at the Pueblo office (WST#76684, seal#37861).

RP heard a noise coming from the kitchen, went up stairs and saw a bear trying to get through the open kitchen window. The bear ate some peaches that were sitting on the windowsill. It ripped the window screen and broke the blinds. RP yelled at the bear and it ran away. 

The RP stated the bear has recently gotten into his bird feeders. There were no bird feeders out when WL 287 did a site inspection. WL 287 verbally warned him about leaving bird feeders up and gave additional bear aware information.

Bear was euthanized by WL 282 on 7/3

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set
Comments: Bear has been getting into their Apple and Peach trees. Was spotted in front of their house in the yard. I set a trap on July 30th at noon.
Juvenile bear in a tree in RP’s backyard. Bear was gone by the time Officers arrived on scene. WL125

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set
Comments:
321 caught a yearling bear a couple weeks earlier. Landowner saw a least 3 bears one night (sow and yearlings) back in June. No other bears were caught. 
Bear came in last night and tipped over grill, broke into tack shed and got into trash. 321 set trap on 7/3. No bear caught or has come back to property. Trap pulled 7/6.

RP stated that this bear took down fences and got into the chicken coop killed 5. This happened last night early morning. Gave the RP hazing advice and let him know about hot wiring and bear mats for the chicken coop. The RP will be sending pictures and a video once received I will add to the report.

 WL 287 did a site inspection,  RP was putting up hot wire on his chicken coop. He buried all the dead chickens. WL 287  offered to set up a pepper barrel RP did not want the pepper barrel near his chicken coop. WL 287 that is the best place to put it because the chickens are the attractant so the barrel should go near the attractant to haze bear away from the attractant. RP declined to put it there and wanted it near the fence to the backyard where he thinks he got it in.  Pepper Barrel was out for three weeks and never got set off. WL 287 also dropped off four unwelcome mats the following Monday after the Bear Aware Volunteers made more. RP declined putting these near the chicken coop as well and  put them by the back fence.

No trap was set due  to having no target bear.  He already cleaned up and fixed the chicken coop so no hair or bear tracks found.  The photo he sent from a neighbors camera of two bear cubs walking through the neighbors driveway was from several weeks prior to the incident. This area has a lot of individual bears.  

RP called back on 10/16/2020 when WL 287 was out of cell coverage about a bear breaking fences. See other report entered.
Woman walked out to her car and bear charged her from across driveway. She jumped in car and drove away.

RP had trash can full of dog food on back porch, looked out back window and saw a medium size cinnamon bear. RP states that she chased the bear through the yard while throwing fire-crackers at it to scare it off.
Dog food has been moved inside and secured.
Pepper barrel was set in the yard and RP was advised to call DWM back if the bear keeps showing up

5/28/2020
Bear entered house through open back door and ate dog food in kitchen. DWM set trap and caught bear approx 20 minutes later. Bear was destroyed per WL220 direction and CPW policy

Rp reported bear passing by her residence this morning. Has seen bears pass by before this season. RP Heard from grounds assistant manager of the Flying Dutchman complex (right across the street) that this bear had been getting into dumpsters and trash. Appears to be yearling bear. Inspected dumpsters at the complex and no obvious violations. Metal lids but no bar across the top. Locking sliding door and one dumpster had a closed exterior shed.

Bear in tree. Large black in color bear. WL324 made site visit. Bear was approximately 25 feet up tree. Tranquilizer and relocation not feasible due to how far off the ground the bear was, and no low hanging branches to climb up in the tree to safely lower the bear down and terrain steepness along the river bank.

Bear broke into a house. Was fighting with her dog downstairs. Was eating food leftover from a birthday party. Windows were open, got in through a screen. RP was finally able to get it out of the house. CSPD Officer saw the bear at the end of the cul de sac. I asked the officer if it was up a tree and he did not think so and that it ran into the woods behind the houses.

WL283 placed a trap at the house. Target bear is a smaller dark brown or black bear that would be the size of last year’s cub or a little bigger. If target bear is caught it should be euthanized. The trap will be pulled in 3 days if no bear is caught.

Trap was pulled. No bear was caught

No Response Needed
RP called to report that he thinks a bear broke into his chicken house and ate 15 of his chickens. The RP raises the chickens as a hobby and not as a business. This morning the RP got back from running errands and went to check his chickens. He saw that the door had been damaged and all 15 of his new chickens were gone. The RP said he did not hear anything and his dogs did not bark at all so he was unsure of when during the night the bear came by. I told the RP that since the bear was rewarded, it will most likely return. The RP said about 5 of his older chickens were unharmed so I told him to be sure to secure the chicken house and to be proactive in using deterrents so that the bear is not rewarded again. I told the RP if he does see the bear he needs to haze it with noise and look into how to build unwelcome mats or set up electric fencing. I offered to send him education materials and he was not interested and said he has lived with wildlife for years and did not want to set up fencing. The RP did not request a call back but WO544 was notified of the report. L. Berry

WL544 did a site inspection. This address was located directly next to an address that had issues with a bear on the 27th. WL544 observes two hummingbird feeders located at the residence. WL544 told the RP that he should take the hummingbird feeders down day and night because the bears are attracted to them. WL544 advised the RP that he should put up an electric fence or unwelcome mat to prevent further damage. RP acknowledges that a unwelcome mat might work. WL544 gave RP information on how to build a electric fence enclosure. RP said that he was going to put up a trail camera. WL544 said that if he was able to pattern and identify a specific bear we can try more aggressive forms of hazing but this would only occurred after he cleaned up his humming bird feeders. 
END

Responded to call on 11/3/20.  Talked directly to Merrill at his home.  I documented bear sign and deployed an electric mat in front of the custom doors.  Merrill speculated that the smell of a pizza that was brought home may have been the catalyst for the bear to investigate.

Complaint Type: Food Source Property Damage , Aggressive Behavior

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials
Comments: Bear got into trash and tipped over their beehive.  Destroyed one of the boxes and ate the brood.  Showed the RP and her husband how to secure trashcan with a ratchet strap.  Offered an 8x8 hobbie bee yard to them but they declined it until later.  They said they were going to move the hive to Penrose for a few weeks and then bring it back.  I explained to them that since materials were offered to protect the hive and were declinesd CPW would NOT be liable for future damage to the hives.  The RP told me that she understood.  I gave her a Living With Bears pamphlet for further recommendations on how to avoid conflicts with bears.
Bear keeps breaking into trash cans.

RP called and informed me that her husband saw a chocolate colored bear during the day.  RP told me she had an empty bird feeder and a bear bent the shepherd's hook that the bird feeder was attached to.

Told her to remove the empty bird feeder and to not have any other bird feeders or bird baths out.  Instructed her to close her windows at night and not leave them open.  Instructed her to make bear mats and put them on her deck if they weren't going to close their bedroom window due to the heat.

Delivered rubber buckshot on 7/14/2020.

Rp stated bear has been getting into trash every night. Dumpster is full and now trash is being placed outside dumpster and inside barn like enclosure that is very accessible to animals. Dumpster has sliding/locking door on side but nothing is securing top flaps so extremely accessible to bears. Waste management is dumpster company. Spoke with Laura Hendrickson from keystone property management who is in charge of ski tip neighborhood. Gave a verbal warning about knowingly luring bears and gave two days for temporary fix and also discussed long term more permanent fixes such as new dumpster, better external housing and different trash company

Anne called to report hearing a gunshot and the seeing a cinnamon bear run onto her property. She said the bear did not look injured. 

I contacted the neighbors across the street, Scott Jorgenson. Scott said the bear was on his deck, broke into his shed, and was trying to get into his vehicle again. Scott said that he shot in the bears direction but was careful not to shoot the bear. I gave Scott some other hazing options, told him not to shoot at wildlife, and talked about removing attractants. WL 522

Ash Tuley reported that his neighbor,James Caldwell, leaves his trash out and the bear has been spreading it around. Caldwell refuses to pick up the trash. An Archuleta County Sheriff's Officer visited Caldwell's residence had other individuals at the residence pick up the trash. On  June 9th, 2020 Wildlife Officer 328 gave Caldwell and verbal warning.

RP is owner of Pagosa Springs Golf Club. Reported to 325 that golfers infomed him that a young brown colored bear was rummaging through a trashcan. 325 responded later that afternoon. Unsecured trash can with trash scattered on back porch as well as trash bin with broken ratchet strap tipped over and accessed by bear. Residents not home, Living with Bears door hanger left.

Staff Assigned: joseph.walter@state.co.us, tyler.stoltzfus@state, mark.lamb@state.co.us, jason.clay@state.co.us, michael.gallegos@state.co.us, jenny.campbell@state.co.us

Comments: RP called about bear with a possible broken leg from falling out of a tree. WL222 responded and found bear carrying its front left paw, and the bear could not climb trees. The bear went into the brush before WL222 could determine the extent of the injury.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials
Comments:
RP told me they have been seeing a bear on their security cameras at approximately 2 AM every night.  RP also told me the  bear was getting into trash they keep in a dog kennel next to their house.

Went to the RP's residence  and they showed me the dog kennel.  The dog kennel was  a section of chain link fence  attached to their house on one side.  The kennel did not have a top and was about 4 1/2 feet in height. 

Recommended they invest in a dumpster with a bear bar, told them to not leave their trash in the kennel and that they have the dumpster placed away from their residence rather than next to it.  I gave her Lone Wolf's contact information.  The RP told me she would get a dumpster with a bear bar.

Also gave her bear aware information, pyrotechnics and rubber buckshot.

Tom reported attempted bear break in at 3am, followed by home entry by the bear at 5am. Small, cinnamon colored bear seen in kitchen before being scared out. Bear returned and attempted entry between 7 and 8 am, but homeowner kept it out, and SO deputies scared the bear off of the property. Trap set for 4 nights, unsuccessfully.
Bear hit by car I-70 at mm175. Bear still alive ECSO dispatched the bear

Complaint Type: Food Source Property Damage , Attack , Aggressive Behavior
Comments: Bear was being fed by homeowner. Bear bit homeowner on hand. Euthanized by CPW officer when it returned later in the morning. Identified by wound that the homeowner inflicted on the bear after the bite (stabbed with sword), as well as injured rear leg. Charges pending for feeding the bear.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set , Relocated
Comments:
Trap initially set by 464 on 7/3/2020, trap malfunctioned night of the 3rd, 465 replaced with another trap on 7/4/2020.  Sow with 2 cubs had been hanging in the trailer park, had tore into skirt underneath one trailer and were coming and going.  Another neighbor reported that the sow and cubs were not scared of people, knocking over trash, and being seen throughout the day.  
Sow was caught in the trap on the night of the 5th, cubs were free darted out of a neighboring tree that morning.  Sow and cubs were tagged and translocated north of Loma near Douglas Pass.

Bear in house through plastic over open window above window cooler. Family did not allow trap as did not want sow/3 cubs destroyed. Damage to foodstuffs in kitchen area. Although family asleep in residence did not hear entry or damage....awoke to mess but bear(s) were no longer inside., left through same open window.

Comments:
Peeled siding off trailer, ground lay and hay saver
talbotss@msn.com

Jennifer said she believes this is the same bear that tried to break into her house and that was in her neighbors house multiple times. Complaint Type: Food Source Property Damage , Sighting , Unsubstantiated
Comments:
*for a full detailed account refer to case report for citation f137130*

On 9/5/20 DWM Goncalves received a call from dispatch about a party, Peterson, who wanted to report that he had shot a bear in his camp.  When DWM Goncalves went to investigate, he gathered the following info:

Peterson came back to his camp on 9/4 around lunchtime and found a show and a cub eating food in their camp. Scared the bears off.

Peterson attempted to clean up most of the food but left a substantial amount that they forgot about.

Came back the next day around lunchtime again and again found the bears in camp. Scared the bears off again.

Tracked the bears about 150 yards from his camp where the sow and cub were up a tree. Shot the sow one time with his 10mm pistol. Left the scene when she came down the tree a little ways.

Went to a neighboring camp to say he had shot a bear if the person in camp wanted to cut it up. Then told them he was going to go call it in. The person in the neighboring camp declined to go get the bear.

Peterson turned himself in.

Peterson told DWM Goncalves he was worried the bears would return that night.

Peterson told DWM Goncalves he was not in fear for his life when the bear was in the tree

Peterson went back to the tree the bear was in and could not find her then looked for an hour and a half and could not find her. Cub was not present either.

DWM Goncalves found one small spot of blood.

Based on the above information DWM cited peterson for hunting without a proper and valid license.

AWM Wenum was contacted by Zummach at 6:10 AM and advised of a possible lion vs. fawn deer predation incident near his back yard in the Dos Rios subdivision SW of Gunnison.  Wenum advised he would respond to the  scene and arrived at approx. 8:10 AM.  Zummach and wife described how they heard what sounded like a lion or bear behind their house and across a small pond that is in their backyard.  About 5:30 they heard bleating/screaming of something and suspected it was a fawn they have been seeing recently in the neighborhood.  After about 15-30 seconds of the sounds they could also hear heavy breathing and the breaking of branches/brush.  They could not see either the deer or lion/bear.  They did see a doe deer in their backyard looking ("anxiously") toward the sounds.  Wenum and Zummach went around to the opposite side of the pond and were able to located and observe some bent over vegetation in areas (some smaller animal paths and some larger foot print areas without discernible tracks) and the small intestines of what appeared to be a fawn deer.  While doing so Wenum observed a doe deer standing nearby watching his actions.   Further checks of the area did not reveal and specific tracks or other deer parts.  Given the time of year and several nearby, recent bear incidents Wenum felt this was likely bear predation.  Zummachs have seen bears in the area in the past and it is very suitable habitat for bears  and  lions but more so in the winter for lions.

No safety issues and no further action at this point.

The bear did not appear to be dangerous and was probably just being curious around the campsite. This is the first time the bear had appeared.

On august 19th WL544 got a call from the north east regional. The office stated that they got a call for an anonymous person that MR. Fitzgerald was feeding bears. The RP then later made a report to operation game thief. WL544 responded to the address where the feeding was occurring. WL544 asked Fitzgerald if he was feeding bears. He denied that he was doing any kind of feeding. WL544 asked if he had bears that came through and Fitzgerald said that he did often have bears come through the area and get into his bird feeders. WL544 asked him to take his bird feeders down to avoid conflict. Fitzgerald said that he would not take his feeders down. WL544 did warn Fitzgerald that if he had bears getting into his bird feeders it could be considered attracting bears which is illegal. Fitzgerald said that he was not attracting bears he was attracting birds. Fitzgerald said that if bears came through then that is what happens. WL544 warmed Fitzgerald that feeding bears is illegal. Fitzgerald continued to say that he was not feeding bears. Fitzgerald did let WL544 walk the property. WL544 asked what the tub of water was for. Fitzgerald said that it was for his dog. WL544 then ended the conversation and Fitzgerald did say that WL544 was welcome to come back anytime.
RP is unsure of when bear hit the beehives.  2  Hives destroyed, bear scat found.  Likely two-3 days old.  No trap set yet as there are no indications the bear has returned

***Duplicate Report from 8/12/20, but reported on 8/16/20***

on August 16th RP, Steve Curry, called CSP to report a sow and 2 cubs breaking into cars on 8/16/2020. The on-call Officer, Rocksund (542) called the RP back. Steve was worried that the 3 bears had no fear of humans and that they where out in the middle of the day. Steve told Rocksund that the neighbor had been feeding bears carrots and sugar. Rocksund asked if Steve had reported this to CPW before and he said no, it was just common knowledge that he neighborhood knew. 
Rocksund asked Steve if they have ever had issues with bears and Steve told Rocksund that last week,  Wednesday August 12th at 10AM, his wife was chased inside by the sow and the bear ran up the porch until wife slammed door.  Steve told Rocksund that his 6year old was playing outside near the driveway and had left the garage open while outside. The sow and cubs investigated the garage a few minutes after the child went inside. Steve's wife let the dog out no knowing the bears where outside and dog barked at bears. Sow chase the dog back onto the porch with the wife standing in the door. Sow slipped on the concrete and slid across porch, unable to go through door. Wife slammed the door when sow was approximately 6' away and bear went away. 
Rocksund asked Steve to report all incident of bear activity, especially when bears are being fed. Steve said he was going to report it because the bears have become no afraid of people, but saw numerous CPW trucks where the feeder lived on Friday August 14th and thought it was taken care of. It was on August 16th that Steve witness the sow and cubs going through vehicles with no fear of humans that he wanted to report the bear's activity. 
Rocksund talked to Steve on the phone and told him to remove all attractants and keep the garage door closed; even leaving it open for a few minutes could allow these bears access. Rocksund talked to a few residence and Steve about reporting all bear activity to CPW. Rocksund told them, the community, that it was on them to eliminate all attractant and haze these bears to save the bear's lives. Rocksund reinforced them that CPW does not want to kill a bear, but would be forced to if the community cannot come together and remove attractants and shut their garage doors. 
Rocksund thanked Steve and the passerby neighbors for their time and willingness to prevent future bear conflict and keeping CPW in mind when conflict does arise.

Westbrook and Doyle responded, located sow and 2 cubs and attempted to haze. See Doyle's report from 8/16/20 near Cochetopa Drive in Larkspur.

Comments: RP thought that a bear got into a shed where he had some chickens.  The door was left open and one of the cages was pulled open.  WL 265 responded and did a site inspection. RP is going to get electric fence around the coop and his other animal pens.  The coop is set up perfectly for bear unwelcome mats so I suggested those and he is going to make some.  Gave him a "Living With Bears" pamphlet for other suggestions on how to minimize conflicts.  Gave him 3 rds of rubber buckshot and he signed a liability release form.  RP has  my card and is going to call me if he has anymore problems.  He did not want the bear trapped.

Brown colored bear visits bear proof dumpster at night and climbs around on dumpster but unable to get in. Also messes with BBQ grill. 
Dilley spoke to RP and campers about leaving any attractant out that would draw in a bear including the trash, food, grills, and bird seed feeders all of which were present around the cabins. Dilley told them to make sure all windows and doors on cabins and vehicles were closed and locked.

Laurie (and Joe) Haney at 10276 West Totem Run, Littleton contacted the office about a green ear tagged bear frequently visiting their yard.  When WL551 called them, Laurie said the bear is constantly in their yard and tearing apart their trees (Gambel's oak) and they are unable to use their yard.  She wanted it moved.  WL551 went over attractants and hazing and told her we would not be moving the bear.  WL551 discussed that Roxborough is prime bear habitat and there will always be bears there, and the importance of hazing. Laurie mentioned the neighbor had a pond and another neighbor had a hummingbird feeder, but Laurie did not have attractants in their yard.  WL551 offered to do a site visit to see if they could come up with other ideas to minimize the bear's time spent in her yard (i.e. habitat modification, etc).  

WL551 met with the Haney's at 4pm on 8/21/20, and based on what was said, this bear was not exhibiting bad behavior.  The scat is composed of fur (maybe rabbit?) and acorns.  The entire side and back of the house is loaded with oak brush and "ripe" acorns.  There was no sign of birdseed or any other human foods.    WL551 recommended they remove some of the oak brush close to their house to open up visibility in their yard.  Joe said they were in the process of doing so.  They also had a small water feature, which WL551 recommended removing, and Joe said he would.  WL551 again talked to them about hazing and Laurie said she can't continue to bang pots and pans (perhaps because it will annoy the neighbors).  WL551 recommended paintball and Laurie said she's not shooting a paintball gun in her yard.  She also doesn't want to throw things at the bear because she doesn't want to be that close to the bear. WL551 asked her what she is willing to do, and she said "Call you."  WL551 told her "No" and that it is her responsibility to haze animals out of her own yard.  WL551 was very clear that we would not be moving the bear since it is in excellent bear habitat and the bear is not doing anything wrong.  WL551 also explained that even if we were in a situation where we would move a bear, this one already had a strike and would need to be put down.  The contact with Laurie ended a little abruptly, since she walked away from WL551 back toward the door of the house.  Joe stayed and listened - he reiterated everything WL551 recommended.

WL551 believes this bear is #1193 which is the mother of white tag #124 (they separated in May-ish).  1193 and 124 were moved from Littleton in July 2019 due to bad location.  They returned to Waterton Canyon within three weeks.  They disappeared for the remainder of 2019 until they both showed up (and separated) this summer.   WL551 08/22/20
Bear rolled bear proof trash can.

On 08/25/2020 Wildlife 261 received a call from the RP. The RP stated that a juvenile bear had broken into their bee hive which was in an apiary fence which CPW provided that morning and knocked down one of the hives. She also stated that a few days earlier the bear had gotten into their trash which they leave outside near their compost pile. WL 261 responded to the location and discovered that the bear had got into the apiary fence by climbing a wooden fence which is extremely close to the electrified fence. WL 261 recommenced moving the apiary away from the fence or removing the wooden fence completely, which the RP stated that they would be taking the wooden fence down. After being show the property by the RP WL 261 discovered that they had chicken feed, a trash bin, and a humming bird feeder around the property. WL 261 recommended putting those items inside at night and locking them up to removed all bear attractants from the area. The RP was very cooperative and agreed to do so. WL 261 also brought a bear spray barrel to the property to haze the animal if it returns.

Small bear around dispersed campsites. RP concerned it might have been an orphan cub.

On 08/21/2020 Wildlife 261 received a call from Parks 1404 (the RP). The RP stated that he had received reports of a bear getting into dispersed camps on the North side of the Arkansas river across from the Salida East Recreation Area. The RP gave a description of the camp that the bear had entered and told WL 261 that the bear had got into pots and pans with food on them that the campers had left in a bug screen near their tent. WL 261 identified this camp as the same camp that he talked to the day before about a bear getting into camp and had informed the campers to put all food, trash and anything with a scent away from their camp and in a tree if possible. The RP also informed WL 261 of a truck camper approximately 100 yards up river of the tent that had a large amount of trash outside it and suspected that the trash was drawing in the bear. He also informed WL 261 that the truck camper had broken down and AHRA was working on a way to get the truck camper removed as soon as they could. WL 261 responded to the location of the where the bear had got into pots and pans near the tent. The campers were not at camp but WL 261 did note that there was food left outside the tent under a bug net. WL 261 then noticed 5 RVs up river of the tent including the truck camper the RP had mentioned had a large amount of trash outside of it. WL 261 made contact or attempted to make contact with all the RVs and informed them that there was bear activity in the area and educated them on locking up food and trash at night in order to not attract bears. When WL 261 contacted the camp with a large amount of trash outside he contacted a male and a female individual. When informed of the bear activity in the area the Male party stated, “ok” and walked away. The female party stated that they had seen the bear and it had tore apart the engine of the truck and punctured the tire on the truck and that is why they could not leave.  She then went on to say that she worked for a secret division of the government that WL 261 probably knew about and stated that she hoped if WL 261 found sawed up human bones that she hopes he would take them to the bone collector. The female party then asked if WL 261 had an evidence bag because she really need one right now, the female party then walked away. From where WL 261 was standing at the time he could not see any evidence that a bear had broken into the truck, but do to officer safety concerns based off the conversation and behavior of the male and female parties WL 261 did not approach the truck camper any further. WL 261 then left the camps and informed WL 260 of what had taken place.

Between the times on 11:00- 11:40 PM WL 261 patrolled the North and South side of the Arkansas River on 08/21/2020. WL 261 noted that the truck camper still had an abundance of trash outside the camper and the camper door was left open.

On 08/22/2020 WL 261, WL 262, and Parks 1404 walked the camping area by the truck camper and tent and handed out "Camping with Bears" fliers to all camps. If campers were not in camp the fliers were left in obvious locations near their campers.

Free range chickens, advised to pen and electrify. DWM HOLDER #754 hit bear with bean bag round and advise neighbors of bear and non lethal shots. Impromptu bear program to 12.

Complaint Type: Food Source Property Damage , Aggressive Behavior
Comments: On Call Wildlife Officer (WL227) received a call from Colorado State Patrol Dispatch that the RP had been attacked by a black bear. WL 227 called WL 223 and requested assistance. WL 220, 223, and 227 responded to R/P's address. The R/P wasnt actually attacked but had tripped and fallen after shooting at the bear after it entered his chicken coop. The R/P informed Officer Brown that he had shot at and hazed the bear earlier in the day after it killed several meat birds. A different bear reportedly came back and broke into the chicken coop. Prior to arrival WL 220 instructed WL 227 to have Custer County deputy Schuh put the bear down. The R/P was given further info on bear proofing his chicken coop via electricity in addition to being offered bear deterrant rounds. The R/P declined the deterrant rounds stating that he didnt have a shotgun. Upon removing the bear WL 223 and 227 noticed a large bulge on the front left shoulder. Upon further examination a rubber slug was removed from the deceased black bear. WL 224 is advised to follow up with the R/P to potentially reduce the chances of future human bear conflicts within the Rosita area.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials

The RP had calmed down substantially, and was receptive, and listened to the tips and tools on avoiding bear conflicts. RP understood that it is not uncommon to see bears in South Fork.

Bear mats were put In front of the doors and windows in the cabin. The cabin is a summer cabin and not fully occupied.

At approximately 12:30 PM Wildlife 261 received a call from the Salida Office stating that there was a bear cub running down Maxwell St. in Salida. WL 261 responded to the area and got flagged down by a pedestrian and the pedestrian stated that there was a bear cub that ran through her yard and up a tree across from Chrisholm Park off of Hunt St. WL 261 responded to the second location and found a sow with two cubs located up a large tree. WL 261 was able to identify the bears as the same three bears that have been in trees in Salida 2 times over the last 3 weeks. WL 261 contacted WL 260 who stated that they should try to tranquilize and relocate the animals if give the chance. WL 261 remained on scene until 9:00 PM when the crowds of people left the area. The sow never came down the tree low enough to safely dart her and therefore no attempt to tranquilize her was made.

Bear appeared to want to stay in the tree so I cleared the scene and notified/educated people recreating in the area.
Bear took bag of livestock feed out of back of unsecured trailer.  WL 225 set a pepper barrel on 6/29/2020.

RP called Chaffee County Dispatch who contacted Wildlife 262 who passed it onto Wildlife 261 the morning of 07/18/2020. Wildlife 261 contacted the RP. The RP stated the bear had knocked over her trash and ate some chicken that had been thrown in there that night. Wildlife 261 educated the individual on how to make her trashcan more bear resistant and informed her that she should try to keep the trash locked up or inside until trash day and to remove all other attractants from around the house at night. Wildlife 261 drove through the ally later that day.

WLO 523 taked with Ben in the early hours of the 15th.  Ben reported that he had confronted a black bear that was attempting to get into the chicken  coop.  Five chickens had been killed by a bear over the past few weeks and the bear was goi g after the remaining two.
Ben stated that he fired a shotgun in the air to frighten the bear off.  But the result was that the bear activity came in the direction of Ben rather than retreating thus Ben fired a second shot and the bear then left.
WLO523 responded to the residents and attempted to meet with Ben in person, however he was not there at that time.  WLO523 set a pepper barrel next to the coop and left a business card on the front door.  WLO523 later attempted to contact Ben over the phone as a follow up.

The pepper barrel was removed on 09-24-2020 by WLO523.

Comments:
Bear killed two chickens...chicken feed and cantalope rhines on ground for chickens. No electric fence. Nolan said bear came at him but old shell in 30-30 would not fire but fence between bear and RP.  Aggressive behavior unsubstantiated

Nolan said bear addicted to sugar as bit in to plastic water gallon jugs (?!). Nolan did not want bear destroyed as claimed to be Native American (Cherokee). Nolan sleeps with doors open, advised not to leave doors/windows open or unlocked.

Bear trapped/destroyed as per AWM Trujillo direction over two chickens.

On 10/20/2020 Wildlife 261 received a call from WL 262 asking WL 261 if he could run up to Coaldale to investigate a bear incident. WL 261 called the Cutty's  Resort where the incident took place and left a message. WL 261 then responded up to the resort. WL 271 contacted the RP and the RP stated that a bear had broke a window to one of the trailers on the property. WL 261 asked if anyone was in the trailer or if the window had been left open. The RP stated that the owners were not at the trailer at the time, and that the window had been left open and that the neighbor had fed the owner's cats that night in the trailer. The RP also mentioned that last week a bear broke the door handle off the exterior of a truck which had a half eaten sandwich left in it over night. WL 261  looked at the damage to the window and informed the RP and the owner of the trailer the importance of closing windows and locking doors at night especially if there is food in either a trailer or a vehicle. The RP mentioned that the bear did not get in to the trailer just broke the lower of the window and ran off. WL 261 offered rubber buckshot but no one on the property had a shotgun that could hold the ammunition. He then gave the RP and the owner some tips on noise making devices to scare the bear off. WL 261 also requested that the RP tell this information to the rest of the resort which the RP agreed to do. The owner was also repairing the broken window that day. WL 261 told both parties to call if they had the bear come back into the resort.

RP called to say she thinks a bear came to her pig pen. Stated her pig feeder was trashed. WL 225 advised putting up an electric fence, which RP did. WL 225 also sat by the pig pen till about midnight.

Eagle PD called and responded to a bear (~250lbs and brown/blonde) that had hit a number of trash cans at homes down town. Bear was treed at the 405 address, and remained there for the majority of the day. Received additional calls throughout the day and into the evening. This bear is likely one of two or three bears that have been increasingly active in Eagle. No follow up needed at this time for this particular call.
