Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set
Comments:
DWM received a voicemail from Andy Dickey, ranch manager for the Elk Creek Ranch, that there had been an incident in which a bear had swatted a man. DWM Gallegos was not far away so he responded immediately. The individual who had the encounter was David Bixby. He had a decent scratch on his lower back, chose not to seek medical attention. DWM Gallegos asked him to explain what happened. From his written statement:
“At approximately 4:15 this afternoon, I was connecting a hose to our outside hose bib (squatted down, low to the ground) and heard a “paw step” followed immediately by a sharp strike to my lower right back, just above the waistline. I screamed and turned to see the bear retreating and stopped about 10-12 feet away up the hill. After calling my wife and dog inside, we observed the bear lingering around the cabin for another 15-20 minutes. By that time, Andy and Melanie, our ranch managers, and other ranch residents had gathered at the bear moved off to the west, up canyon.”
DWM Gallegos learned that the ranch manager had been called, and he shot the bear with a bean bag round (given to him previously to haze bears). The bear moved away from the area.  DWM Gallegos looked for the bear, but didn’t locate it, so he set a trap. AWM Basagoitia was advised once cell coverage was available.
On the morning of 7/10, DWM Gallegos received a text from the Bixby that the bear had not come back overnight.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set
Comments:
YES reached out to WLO 527 by phone, got vm, text next.  Then will give to on call if I don't hear back soon.

Bear entered home last night through the 3" plywood boarded window broken by bear last Sept. while owner was sleeping last night and got sugar and into the refrigerator.  He is thinking a barrel needs to be set.  Said an officer would be in contact.  T.Wallace NERO

WL 527 and 525 responded and set box trap from Mt Evans on 7/9. Bear is large in sized based off track size. 7/10 bear entered trap and was able to back out and was not caught WALTER 

7/20 bear came back and pushed through a glass door and entered the kitchen area and got into sugar. 527 re baited trap. 

7/21 bear came back to the door and ripped off plywood that RP had fixed the door with and entered the kitchen again.

7/22 527 replaced box trap with the green culvert trap from Mt Evans. Trap and camera were set. RP made a large bear mat covering the entire deck. Bear came back the night of 7/22 and was caught on camera but did not enter the trap. Bear caused no damage on 7/22. RP sent photos of bear prints. Large bear hind prints roughly 8 inches long. WALTER

Trap pulled by 527
A saw with a cub had been hanging around the resort. The bears had been trying to get into trash cans, but the cans are Bear proof. The bear had been eating berries and apple along the river.

WL124: Bear tried to enter Tyndal cabin.  RP who is security for the YMCA contacted the person staying at the cabin who told him he heard a noise coming from the living room and got up to look and then said the bear was trying to crawl through the window and he yelled and the bear ran away. Bear ripped screen off two windows and front door screen.

Complaint Type: Food Source Property Damage , Non-Food Property Damage

Comments: Trap set at home on 7/22 for chicken killing/aggressive bear.  RP heard dogs barking, went outside saw bear in chicken coop.  Dogs ran it up a tree in front yard.  RP shot bear, and called CPW.  Seal #37189.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set , Euthanized
Comments: RP called WL321 and said that they had a bear that got into a cabin and then poked his head into another house while it was occupied. The bear was tearing into the trash can lid, but was unable to get into it cause it was locked. RP tried scaring the bear away but only walked a few yards away. WL321 set a trap on 7/29. Bear caught and trap pulled on 7/30.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials
Comments: Bear got into unsecured trash and two bags of chicken feed that were sitting unsecured in the bed of a truck. RP advised to trash and to get an electric fencing set up for chicken coops. Bear intern issued unwelcome mat. Will call to pick it up on 07/20.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Hazed , Relocated
Comments:
CSPD was called to a bear that was in a dumpster. The bear was not afraid of people and the PD hazed the bear with their sirens and PA from 5 feet away and it did nothing. The bear then got into a dumpster and they Pepper sprayed it. The bear was not phased.

There has been numerous encounters of this bear in the area documented in other apps

Type of Property Damage: Trash , Vehicles , Outside Food Source , Other
Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials , Pyrotechnics
Comments:
I, WL367, visited Dan Grey's residence on 07/16/2020. I ran into neighbor who said the bear was at their residence as well. Neighbor was 17 year old Kodiak Reigel. Kodiak showed me around his property and residence. Alot of trash was taken from the back of their pickup where the trash is stored uncovered. Kodiak stated the bear broke into their other pickup through the back window and ate a bag of peanuts. There was several types of birds running around including geese, chickens, and turkeys. The bear got into the feed containers for the livestock but did not bother the livestock who are roaming about freely. I informed Kodiak and also his father Jim Reigel who i spoke to on the cell phone that they need to pickup and secure their trash and any attractants or the bear would come back and do more damage if a food source is readily available. I left non-lethal bear  deterrants with Kodiak with verbal permission from the father. 

Kodiak took me to Dan Grey's residence. Dan stated that the bear got into his beer cans and some trash. I told Dan to lock up his trash and to keep his bird feeding to a minimum and in-between a specific time frame as well. Dan was left with non-lethal materials as well.

Complaint Type: Food Source Property Damage , Non-Food Property Damage

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set , Pyrotechnics
Comments:
Canterbury called on 7/24/2020 and told me a bear learned how to open a sliding window attached to his mud room.  He told me the bear went in through the sliding window and then took a  bag of dog food.  He stores his dog food in the mud room.  He told me after that happened, on another date,  the bear must have been pushing on the door and the bear somehow managed to turn the door knob and get in.

Note-there wasn't any property damage.  The bear took dog food from the mud room.

Canterbury also told me there were several bears around and that another, much larger bear had been getting into his dumpster.  I recommended that he get a bar and place it on the dumpster to prevent the bear from getting in.

I set a trap on 07/24/20 and gave him pyrotechnics.  

After having the trap set for four nights I pulled the trap on 7/28/2020  and asked them to call me if the bear came back.  When I took the trap they told me they put a bar on top of the dumpster.

RP called to report a small bear cub without mother frequenting area near her home. RP reported bear cub was on property Thursday (6/4) and her dogs spooked up a tree by house. RP reported bear cub was back near house this morning, walked around patio furniture, scratched at back door to house, and walked back near tree where observed previously before leaving. 

Nicholson responded, observed peanuts on ground near tree where cub visited. CPW captured another orphaned cub nearby and transported to rehab last week. Reports have continued about another bear cub in area without a sow. Video of that cub is consistent with this cub, and believed to be sibling of cub already taken to rehab.  

Nicholson art cage trap for cub beside tree where peanuts were on ground. RP has Nicholson’s phone numbers and will update daily of trap condition. Nicholson advised RP not to touch any animals caught in trap.

Entered by Nicholson at 6:45pm on 6/6/2020.

Removed trap and reset at another residence on 6/9/2020. Entered by Nicholson

RP sent Nicholson a text with photo on  6/22, advising she saw cub on property again. RP advised cub ate a flytrap then moved on. Entered by Nicholson on 6/23/2020.
Tenants warned about trash cans being left out.  Tenants hours later sent pics of new bear resistant trash can

Type of Property Damage: Vehicles , Outside Food Source , Orchards/Growing Crops

Comments:
Went to RP's location after being notified by Fremont Deputy Sanger who told me RP had a bear around their house on a couple of occasions.  RP told me the bear was seen 2 times in the last two weeks.  

Told RP they should remove suet feeders, hummingbird feeders and their grill.  Recommended planting flowers to attract birds rather than have feeders out.
-RP showed me a picture of the bear.  Bear did not have tags.
-RP was offered rubber buckshot, but didn't take it since she wasn't familiar with operating a shotgun.  Advised her to use an air horn when the bear is around.

Note-Do not know an actual time and date doesn't reflect the actual date the bear had been at their residence.

Bear coming up on back porch. Looking at back door, but not trying to get into the house.
325 responded on 8/5. Described the bear as dark brown and very large, as tall as her shed when it stood up on her deck. Had minimally secured trash bin that bear continually gets into, but has a bear resistant bin ordered. 325 offered unwelcome mat, but denied because she was worried neighborhood pets would get hurt.

Krista Pontius called CSP to report that the neighbors at 4994 and 5002 has left their trash out and a bear had gotten into the trash on yesterday and that a Jack McCrab had been cleaning up the trash with a rake at about 9pm last night.
WL523 drove by the area mid morning and noted three trash cans placed along the road way near the shared driveway to 4994 and 5002.  
The RP stated that the people living at 4994 are renting the home and are new tenants from the ones that WL523 contacted the year before.  
RP also stated that Jack McCrab is the landlord and she believes that he might have a mental illness.  
WL523 made WL525 aware of the ongoing issues in this area with trash and bears as he has been addressing the issue.
It  was also noted that two of the trash cans were of a "bear resistant" design.  However, these cans will not prevent a bear from getting into them if they are left out, but they are still better than a totally unsecure trashcan.

RP called CSP dispatch today and requested to “retract” her complaints. RP told dispatcher she spoke with the neighbors she had been complaining about and they were doing what they could to prevent bear problems with their trash. Entered by Nicholson on 6/19/2020.
1 Lamb was killed.  Hide was peeled off carcass consistent with Bear kills.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Hazed , Educational Materials , Pyrotechnics
Comments: DWM Brown traveled to RP's address and discovered an unsecured bear proof dumpster in addition to lots of trash scattered in the RP's yard as well as the neighbors yards. Instructed RP and her roommates to pick up all the garbage in addition to securing the bear proof dumpster. The RP was provided bear deterrant rounds and Officer Brown was able to haze the bear via the use of bean bag rounds later that evening.  DWM Brown also provided the neighbors with bear deterrant rounds and pyrotechnics to help haze the animal in the event it returned. DWM Brown learned that the RP has had their trash scattered throughout the yard for almost a month and that they've made no effort to pick it up even when it ends up in their yards! DWM Brown provided the neighbors with contact info for Mountain Disposal so a bear proof dumpster could be obtained.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials , Pyrotechnics
Comments:
RP called at 6:45am to advise a sow and cub got into cooler of food on picnic table in Buffalo Campground around 4:30am. RP advised the sow is currently up a tree and sow “hanging around” area. RP advised about 170 people in campground. 

Nicholson advised to clear that area of campground and keep people away so the cub can come down tree. Nicholson advised cub will stay up there if people don’t stay away. RP said they would clear that area of campground. Nicholson provided his cell number to RP.  RP advised they had seen bear activity since June with bears attempting to get in dumpsters. RP called back at 7:10am and advised they cleared area of campground and the cub came down and left without incident. 

Nicholson responded to campground and met with RP’s. They advised bears have visited the lower dumpster and upper dumpster in campground. They advised they tell everyone who registers in campground to keep food and trash locked up, but some people are resistant to doing so and say they have never been told to before. They advised their supervisor never told them what to do if bears came in campground, and they had never been provided with any notification procedure to request assistance from CPW. 

Nicholson set pepper barrel by lower dumpster and posted bear activity sandwich board on entry to campground near fee station. Nicholson gave CPW notice to remove attractants to RP’s and advised they can show notice to any visitors and advise the campground has a legal mandate from CPW to lock up trash and food because of bear activity. Nicholson advised they should kick anyone out of campground who fails to comply. Nicholson recommended they get paintball gun to haze any bears that enter the campground area: Nicholson provided his business card with CSP and CPW office phone numbers to contact if they have additional bear problems or questions. Entered by Nicholson in 8/15/2020

Pepper barrel and sign were removed by WLO523 on August 24th as there has not been any reports of recent bear activity in the camp grounds.

Scott Trudeau called Wildlife Technician Ryan Lane and informed him that a bear got into their fish pond and did some damage. Lane called Wildlife Officer Sturdevant and told him the details of the incident.
WO Sturdevant called Luke Hoffman, Game Damage coordinator for CPW, and asked if that would be something CPW would cover. Hoffman informed Sturdevant that CPW only covers raw agricultural products.
WO Sturdevant called Scott Trudeau and asked if they produced any raw agricultural products with the pond. Trudeau said no, that it was just a gold fish pond. WO Sturdevant explained that CPW does not cover personal property and that he could still fill out a game damage claim. WO Sturdevant told Trudeau that since it wasn't something that was covered under CPW laws and regulations that it would be denied in the end. Trudeau became upset, said some things and hung up on WO Sturdevant. 
WO Sturdevant went to the property and gave the game damage paperwork to Trudeau and looked at the damage. WO Sturdevant explained that they need to take down the attractants (bird feeders) or else it will just attract more bears. They said they dont keep much feed in it. WO Sturdevant gave Trudeau his card and told them to call if there were anymore problems. Contact ended

Complaint Type: Food Source Property Damage , Aggressive Behavior

Comments: sow 481 with 2 cubs broken into RP chicken coop on night of May 8, killing 3 chickens. RP called dispatch morning of 5/9. 128 responded and, with Boulder Deputies and animal control, located 481 with both cubs in a tree near NW corner of RP property, but across fence on neighbors property. Decision made to leave bear, 127 contacted neighbor to notify them of the bear. 128 did site inspection of damaged coop, provided suggestions for electric fencing and keeping dogs close, and provided 5 rounds of rubber buckshot. No further action needed.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials
Comments: Bear got into trash last night.  WL265 went out and did a site inspection.  Showed him how to secure the trashcan with a ratchet strap.  He put a strap on it immediately.  Gave him a Living With Bears pamphlet for additional recommendations for avoiding bear conflicts.  He has my number and I asked him to call if he has anymore conflicts.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set
Comments:
RP took a walk and noticed that neighboring house had window broken out and saw food and trash scattered outside (came from inside).  Just down the road from where WO Sralla set culvert trap.   Unsure if this break in just happened, or, back when WO Sralla set trap down the road.
W.O Behncke inspected cabin and boarded window.  home Owners we’re notified but live on front range.  WO Behncke set cage trap near front door (see pic).  RP Doug was told to call WO Huntington in the morning with status of trap.
WL483- Trap removed with no success-JH

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set , Hazed
Comments: Through dispatch, Officer Kay spoke with Don Cole from Keystone Security. Officer Kay was at a training and could not respond but advised Don over the phone. Don was on scene when yearling bear entered crepe shop in river run while it was still very light out. Don opened the window the bear had entered through to allow easier exit. Bear eventually came out, but did not appear worried, and was not afraid of people in the area. Despite yelling, bear did not leave area. SO showed up and tried to haze bear with human presence and yelling, but did not leave area. Officer Kay advised SO to use taser or bean bag. SO bean bagged the bear, and it eventually left, but not for about 1.5 hrs. Don from Keystone said this bear had been breaking into and eating out of dumpsters and other food sources consistently over the last few weeks and was recognizable by its size, color and apparent hump in its back. Officer Kay had heard other reports of a bear consistently hitting dumpsters in the area that matched the description. Upon inspection of the crepe shop, it did not appear that any damage was done to the windows or building, indicating the window was either open, or unlocked and easily openable. Officer Kay spoke to owner of crepe shop, Lucas Krill, and warned him about leaving windows open, and that if did not secure his restaurant, would be issued a citation next incident. Krill insisted the windows were shut and locked, and was not sure how bear got in.  Krill said the bear got into nutella, honey and brown sugar. Krill also said he had over 50 lbs of rotten bananas inside the shop that he had forgotten about.The next day, Don reported to Officer Kay that the same bear had been spotted eating out of a dumpster at Sunrise Employee Housing, at approximately 1130 hrs. Officer Kay set a trap that evening near the keystone conference center.  Trap was set for three nights, but no bear activity in keystone area during that time. Trap was taken down on 6/6. Yearling bear was potentially spotted near Keystone Gulch on 6/8

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials
Comments:
Gene Hewitt called CSP Dispatch a couple of times. One time around 11:30 PM the night of June 26 and another at about 2:30 am the morning of the 27th. Wildlife Officer Martinez was on a Bear call when this one aired and a Costilla County Deputy responded. He told dispatch the bear was not around and the mobile home trailer may have some damage to it. Hewitt called back and told dispatch she was going to jump out of her window and make a run for it. 
     Wildlife Officer Martinez visits Hewitt along with a different Sherriffs Deputy later that night after she called dispatch the second time. Upon making contact, there was no bear visible or no sign of bear prints were observed around the residence. The lady was somewhat cooperative in removing the three dogbowls she had on the porch in front of the main entrance to the residence. She was told that a bear would be attracted to the food she puts out for the dogs and was told to feed the dogs in the day and put the bowls away at night. She seemed to be confused in different aspects of her story and kept showing her dogprints and saying they were bear prints.

WL 482 received call just after 7 am about a bear in a car. GCSO was contacted and asked to respond.   I called RP and advised I was headed there. A neighbor let the bear out 10 minutes before we arrived. Vehicle is destroyed on inside.  Vehicle had cannabis inside (see photo).  Also had a soft lunchbox in back that was empty and a vanilla air freshener in cup holder. 4 other cars in driveway had bear prints at door handles. All had the doors locked. I advised owner to remove all food, air freshener, gum and any containers that had food in them and to lock the car doors. WL 482

The bear has visited the property the last three nights
Broken into a shed destroying the door.
RP stored trash, chicken feed, and dog food in the shed that the bear has gotten into.
RP also has a freezer in the shed but did not report that the bear got into it.
Chicken coop with 10 chickens but it is electrified and the bear has not got into the chickens since they electrified.  Earlier in the season, RP lost two chickens to a bear.
There is a six-year-old child at the residence
RP has three dogs that are kept penned up or inside.  I advised to not "sick" the dogs on the bear, RP agreed.
This bear only seems to visit late at night
RP said she has some arrow blunts.  I advised adding some additional duct tape so as to not break the bear's skin.
RP owns a 12ga shotgun


Volunteer provided some nail boards and electric mat and less-lethal 12ga rounds.
I will plan a site assessment and advise.  I think, sight unseen, that they would do well to electrify the shed(s) as well.
I will advise putting the nail boards up whenever the 6-year-old is out.  I will also advise on the use of bear spray and warn about shooting the bear with lethal.  RP understands and doesn't want to destroy the bear but is determined to defend the child should it come to that.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set , Hazed , Educational Materials
Comments:
Bear came into the camp ground and ate food left out by campers in a paid Forest Service camp ground. Wildlife 266 responded and educated the campers in the area to put lock away food when not cooking or eating and to remove all attractants. Wildlife 266 also hazed the bear using cracker shells and other noise making devices. 

On the morning of 07/18/2020 the bear returned at approximately 9:40 AM and got into marshmallows and Gatorade left out by campers. Wildlife 266 responded and educated the campers in the area again about the importance of locking away food when not in use. Wildlife 266 again hazed the bear using noise making pyrotechnics.  The RP believed at this time that there were two different bears in the camp, distinguishable because one had a white patch on its chest. RP believed bears to be approximately 200 lbs. In between the time Wildlife 266 left the area that day at 2:30 PM the bear or bears returned 2 more times. Once was just a sighting and one time the bear leaned up against an unoccupied tent. No damage was done to the tent. Wildlife 261 responded and set a trap in the best available location in the campground and walked to each individual site in the camp ground and instructed campers that attractants had to be put away and locked up when not in use, and made them aware that a trap was being set. The trap was set at 6:20 PM and the RP was informed on how to use it.

No bear was trapped on the morning of 07/19/2020.

Complaint Type: Food Source Property Damage , Non-Food Property Damage
Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set , Pyrotechnics
Comments: RP stated that a bear broke into her son’s truck last night and damaged door handle and inside of truck. RP did not believe there was any food in the truck but the bear did get into some home insulation last was in truck. WL 330 did a site visit and learned from RP that a sow with 3 cubs had started coming around toward the end of June and had been getting into her bear resistant dumpster. She said that the sow would lift the metal lid up off the corner (even though the lids were chained and locked) to get trash. She had started using a ratchet strap on the corner and that worked. RP also stated that a bear or bears broke into her son’s RV camp trailer and got some food out of it approximately 4 nights ago.  RP believes that the damage is being done by the sow and cubs. RP stated that there are only 2 cubs with the sow now and not 3. No attractants were out on visit and RP said that she has kept things cleaned up.  Trap set 7/19. Rp checked the trap on the morning of 7/21, the door was shut. Rp thought cub got into trap and sow let it out. No food was eaten from the trap. After reviewing the camera, one of two cubs tripped the door from the outside and shut the door without any being captured. On 7/29 trap was pulled no bears captured. Rubberbuck was issued on  7/27.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials
Comments:
RP is the owner of the house but he is not at the residence; he has someone taking care of it.  He is just reporting it.   Bear has broken into the house two nights in a row.

     
I, WL367 called the Christopher (landowner/RP) and left voicemail. I visited the property the next day and met with Debra Schultz (602-513-1463), who takes care of the house. Debra showed me around the house inside and out. There was several areas of forced entry by a bear. This house has not had occupants inside as it is used for seasonal use. The eastern window and the northern upstairs door were both entry points. Another door on the west side had a broken screen. The bear was all over the residence both downstairs and up. The kitchen was the main attractant for the bear as it opened and destroyed all types of food sources. 
     
Debra and I had a long detailed conversation about how to bear proof the home and how to live with wildlife. Many tips and tricks were given to prevent this event from happening in the future. 

Debra reported that there would be unwelcome mats put in on 7/20/2020.

RP stated at approximately 9:30 pm, bear was at his residence. Bear was rooting around near hot tub. RPs large dog barked at bear and bear paid no attention. Bear moved off and came back later in the evening. Bear tore up hot tub cover. RP stated this was the third cover that has been torn up.

Complaint Type: Food Source Property Damage , Sighting , Aggressive Behavior
Comments: 128 went to talk with Lisa at 40440 (small yellow house) who has had the bear break in 5 times this summer and once into her truck which was destroyed. She loves the bear and does not want it to be killed. She showed me a video she took of the bear coming out of her truck from about 15 feet away, the bear did not seem to care that she was there. Looks like the same bear from 40420 and Marine street issues. Lisa did not want to send me the pictures but said she would call if another incident happened. We talked about home security, trash security and removing attractants. She also admitted that she had put out food for the raccoons that the bear had eaten, but she would stop doing that. I told her that if she is able to report issues quickly we can respond by hazing and bear activity won't escalate to the point of needing relocation or euthanasia.

Sow with 2 cubs relocated. Had been causing issues (primarily trash) in area for a few weeks. Sow is green 477, PIT 982.00364298337. Black cub has white ear tag 118 (treat as a green ear tag, ran out of green tags), brown cub is green 1067. Released by WL124.

Complaint Type: Food Source Property Damage , Non-Food Property Damage
Comments: Bear broke into outside shop and took dog food. Bear broke through glass door on shop. Advised homeowner to board door and secure shop and remove all attractants. Homeowner stated that they were going to try an old electric fencing on door.

Complaint Type: Food Source Property Damage , Non-Food Property Damage
Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set , Euthanized
Comments: RP stated that a bear broke into his shop and chicken coop last night on the 10th and ate some chicken feed and 14 chickens. Door handle was broken and the RP had it fixed when 327 and 321 arrived. 327 confirmed bear tracks next to the shop. Trap was set at 4:45pm on the 11th. Bear was trapped in 12th it attempted to enter building before getting in trap. Seal 35685
Bear in tree near condos. No obvious attractants and not causing any problems currently.
Bear Killed 2 lambs and 3 ewes.
Sow had two cubs. One was stuck in a roll off dumpster. A ladder was placed in the dumpster and the smallest of the two cubs climbed out. Family was reunited. No further action taken.

442 received a call from CSP Craig dispatch about a bear in a tree in the RPs yard. 442 called the RP and learned they had heard a noise outside and went to investigate and scared a young bear into the tree.
442 advised to leave the bear alone for the night and it would eventually come down. Earlier that day 442 delivered rubber buckshot to the RPs neighbors and it is likely the same bear. 442 advised RP that he would deliver rubber buckshot to him tomorrow (8/9) and the goal was to haze the bear so it would leave the area. The RP agreed to this. Rubber buckshot delivered the afternoon of 8/9.

Heard alpacas making alarm calls. RP went outside and saw bear climbing the fence were the alpacas are. Also heard alpacas the night before alarm calling. RP has rubber slugs. Left bear spray barrel at residence.  After speaking with RP and inspecting location it is improbable that bear was climbing over fence into alpacas.

Rp neighbor sent him this email.
In short, it is clear that a bear got into your yurt, causing serious
damage to the yurt shell and three windows, as well as extensive
damage to the interior contents.  From the looks of it this happened
when we were away, probably days ago.

Summit Cove Vacations Lodging Rp is renting for the summer. A bear has been coming every day the residence - next door has a dumpster that isn't secured and is in it every day. Seems as though the bear is being encouraged to stick around. - SC HSS

RP advised she and her husband and son, were fishing at swim beach at Willow Creek Reservoir. She advised they had stopped for McDonalds in Granby and had coffee with them. She advised bear walked up behind them and her son said something about it. They left their items and walked to the north away from the parking lot. Bear walked up to their items and sniffed around. Then walked towards them. Sounds like in the same direction. RP stood up, waved her hands and bear walked away. RP and family went to car. Bear approached the car, didn’t touch it, walked to dumpster and left the area. They picked up their items after CSP and GCSO arrived and couldn’t locate the bear. I received the call from CSP about a bear that had people trapped in their car. That was not the case after speaking with  Bell from GCSO.   Parties moved to other end of lake.  Talked about bear behavior with parties. No further action needed.

No further response as of now.

WL541 received a report from the RP that a large dark brown colored bear with a green ear tag in the left ear was in Tucker Gulch around 7:00pm.  It matched the description of the bear that had been hanging around Tucker Gulch and hitting trash cans within the neighborhood since last week.   
WL545, WL546 and WL541 responded to try to haze the bear.

The bear was followed around Golden and hazed with noise and lights until it crossed over Highway 58 and was lost in the vegetation surrounding Clear Creek.

Complaint Type: Food Source Property Damage , Sighting , Aggressive Behavior
Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set
Comments: RP advised bear ran into her back yard and came up to her window and broke it out. She advised she does have seed and hummingbird feeders. Advised she remove them and she advised she did. Bear broke window and ran away. Trap was set that night. Window was covered with plywood. RP does have dog and cat inside residence.  Did not trap bear, trap was removed after three days.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials
Comments: RP called and was concerned about her neighbor, and that she was putting the scraps from meals outside for wildlife to eat. RP said that the neighbor told her that it was “for the critters” to eat. A bear has now been frequently been in the RP’s back yard. RP doesn’t want to ruin relationships, and asked if DWM Gallegos could be discreet. He said that he would put up some door hangers in the neighborhood that would hopefully help her start the conversation with her neighbor to quit putting food out.

RP called to report bear actively getting into bear resistant trash can. Took can off porch and rolled into area between condos and broke into can despite clasps etc. Officer Kay went to haze the bear and could not find it, but spoke to many neighbors and advised them to be bear aware etc.  Bear was tagged with red tags, and could be area 8 bear that was recently released into area 9. Around 1830 hours, neighbor called to report bear back in area. Bear was near the Salt Lick trailhead and I-70 in the woods. While waiting there Officer Kay saw the bear begin to head back to Salt Lick neighborhood. Officer Kay followed the bear and began to approach and yell at it once it got close to houses. Bear was overall not scared or intimidated by human presence, and would run off only 20-30 yards when approached at close range. Officer Kay eventually got a clear shot and shot one round of rubber buck. Bear ran about 30 yards and stopped. It became dark and the bear was last seen nestled in a gully near the neighborhood.

Sandidge killed a bear earlier in July, he wanted to report that another bear has been in the area. Getting his and his neighbors trash. Stated he didnt want to kill another bear for getting in his trash and being close to his home where he has young kids. I told Sandidge a bear getting into the trash doesnt justify killing it. I provided him with rubber buckshot to use as a deterrent

WL124: RP watches over neighbor's (absent landowner) house when they are gone. RP stated that within the past two weeks a bear broke through the screened in porch and then broke through the door into the cabin. The bear went foraged the kitchen cabinets and refrigerator  and got a food reward. Provided RP with rubber buckshot rounds.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials , Pyrotechnics
Comments:
WL 284 called to ask if bear aware volunteers could assist WPPD with a bear in an unoccupied, house being built in the Stoneridge subdivision.  When BA  arrived WPPD Officer Mike had already cleared the house and the bear(s) were gone.  The bears were reported to have moved SW along the green belt.  The sow and cubs appear to move off when hazed but stroll through the neighborhood when not confronted.

A construction dumpster in front of the house has non-construction trash in it and about half full is the attractant.  Per Terri Collins the bears have been frequenting the dumpster attracting a crowd wanting to see the bears and take pictures.  

We spoke to several residents in the area.  They confirmed the bears are frequenting the dumpster regularly. 

Terry Collins said she was going to contact the general contractor so they can request that they don't throw non-construction trash into it.  I asked the neighbor across the street, at 1314, to call if the bears showed up again.  

Drove around the subdivision and spoke to anyone with garage doors open.  Also drove around the Northwood subdivision.


Recommendation:
Speak to the construction crew about having the dumpster dumped as it is an attractant.
Canvass the subdivision to education about being bear aware

Bear tearing up a dumpster. It is bear proof but it was ripping the plastic on the lid. Concerned for the safety of children and others in the area. Would like to be contacted since bear has been around. - SC HSS

Bear entered loading dock enclosed area through open roll up door. Bear was in dumpster inside dock.   Bear climbed into ductwork of ceiling.  RP place 2×4 against duct for bear to climb down. Bear climbed down and Dilley chased out of dock area. Dilley advised to keep roll up door closed when not actively entering or exiting.

Bear was in ditch, RP drove by and bear cub ran out and hit back tire of truck. Bear appeared to have broken front left foot and leg. Bear ran down into flat area and was laying in bushes and grass S. of road. WL321 was unable to locate

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Trap Set , Educational Materials , Pyrotechnics

Comments: On 09/23/2020 Wildlife 261 received a voice message from the RP stating that a bear had broken into his garage, got locked inside and then tore up a dog door in order to get out of the garage. WL 261 then contacted the RP. The RP stated that a sow with a single cub had been seen around his house earlier that week. He then stated that earlier the day of the incident he had installed the dog door into the swing door of his garage. He had left the door propped open that night. At around 10:30 PM the sow and cub entered the garage through the open door and got to the open dog food which was in the garage. At some point the door closed behind the bears and they could not leave the way they came in.  After some time of running through the garage the sow and cub finally exited the garage through the dog door which was destroyed in the process. The RP also had noticed that something had got into his dog food in the garage a few weeks prior while the door was opened but thought it was just a stray dog in the area.  WL 261 contacted WL 266 who was closer to the address to respond and perform a site inspection. WL 266 gave the RP a couple unwelcome mats to put near the dog door and issued him some rubber slugs to help haze the bears if they are seen again.

Received a  call from Francis Livings who told me Bob Muth has been seeing a bear in his yard off and on.  She told me that he told her it had a limp and it may be injured.  She told me the bear was in his yard at that time.

I went to Muth's residence and  the bear was not there.  Muth did not have any bear attractants.  His property is adjacent to BLM land with excellent bear habitat.

We hiked around his property and we didn't see the bear.  As I was leaving he ran out of his house and told me the bear was back.  We then observed the bear in his backyard.  The bear had a limp and possibly an injured front left leg.  I did not think the injury warranted the bear being euthanized.  The bear "spooked" and sprinted away.  

I gave Muth rubber buckshot and asked him to shoot the bear if it came into his yard again.  I asked him to not shoot it if it was out on the BLM land where it belonged.

Bear was an average sized brown colored black bear.  It did not have eartags.

While talking to Muth he told me he had seen three other bears, but since this other, larger bear showed up he hasn't seen the other bears.

Asked Muth to call me if he needed more rubber buckshot.  When the fire ban is lifted I will give him M-80s.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set , Euthanized
Comments:
Young looking bear has been hanging around the area for a few weeks. Bear has gotten into two homes in the area and many trash cans. Homes had doors left open.  Most people have secured their trash and other attractants. RP is interested in getting a trap set. He has a large riparian area next to his house where a trap could be set.
321 called and talked to RP about possibly doing a site visit and setting a trap. Set a trap on 8/17. Bear caught on 8/18 around 5 am. RP stated that the bear has gotten into 2 homes and a garage and has no fear of humans

RP relorted a bear had gotten in his trash last week and that he then began storing the trash in the barn. Bear then got in barn to access trash. WL521 met with landowner and provided information on attractants and hazing methods. WL521 also set a pepper barrel at the barn.

Young bear in the area, RP concerned about alpacas. W328 advised RP on how to minimize the bears activity at her locatio.  To trash cans outside, bear had not been into them. RP will secure trash. W328 provided rubber slugs for RP's shotgun.  Alpacas are kept inside at night. RP cell phone(970) 799-2872

Landowner mentioned that their trash cans had been get knocked over the last few nights.  

A young lamb had a large portion of skin on its face peeled off. Landowner believes it was the bear.  No tracks were found.  But something got ahold of that lamb.
Bear killing domestic sheep

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set
Comments: Subadult was chased out of the campground by the host multiple times. When I arrived the bear was on the hill next to the campground. I chased it off. It had gotten into a camp sites potato chips. I set a trap outside of the campground after coordinating with Katie Harris the FS LEO. I also spoke with each camp and informed them about the bear and to lock all attractants up. On the night of July 23rd the bear was trapped and relocated that morning.

PD asked me to respond because the homeowner needed help handling the situation in the future. The PD said the homeowner was able to call the bear out of the tree and get it to leave the area (like a dog). The homeowner told me and the PD multiple times that he has not fed the bear. I responded and the homeowner showed me where the bear was but it was gone upon my arrival so I was not able to view the behavior/habituation. Discussed with the homeowner hazing the bear and keeping windows and doors locked.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials
Comments:
RP advised Dena Barton moved to address in November 2019, has left trash outside piles up on porch and drive of residence. RP advised bears are getting into trash now and dragging all over property and neighboring property. RP advised Dena Barton works at  VCA animal hospital, has phone number 304-904-0394.

Nicholson responded, confirmed trash attractants (see photos), found boxes dog food with Barton’s name torn open by bear. Nicholson left notice on door advising legal requirement to remove attractants with his business card. 

Nicholson called Barton, verbally warned for failing to remove attractants, advised criminal and possible civil liability if bear broke into a home. Barton acknowledged understood and said would have trash removed tomorrow. Nicholson left message for landlord advising of situation. 

Entered by Nicholson on 5/6/2020.

RP sent video and photo of sow with 2 cubs eating the packages of dog food outside this residence on night of 5/6/2020. RP advised trash and attractants were cleaned up on 5/7/2020. 

Entered by Nicholson on 5/8/2020.
RP called to report deer possibly shot in her driveway. 325 responded, fawn not shot, was killed and partially fed on by bear. 325 removed carcass.
Wiseman called to report that they had found a calf that appeared to have been killed by a bear. WL428 investigated and found evidence of bear predation at the site.

Bear broke in several days ago. Got into same door as incidents from previous years. Bear made it past several unwelcome mats. Bear received food reward including essential oils. Unknown bear description. Neighbor thinks it’s a juvenile bear black in color. Provided advise and set up trail camera.
Bear was in Pueblo city limits near shopping center. Pueblo pd responded and treed the bear. WL 222 and 220 showed up and darted the bear.

RP has been dealing with a bear for about a week. Bear kept coming back consistently. RP tried hazing and taking in all his trash. RP had an alarm set on a motion detector to try and scare the bear away. At around 2am the RP’s dog was barking so he let him out. The RP’s dog then started barking and eventually scared off the bear for a moment. The bear did come back even while RP was standing outside with his dog. RP felt the bear was being aggressive approaching him and his dog. RP stated he was scared the bear was going to break into his house next. When the RP came out the next morning he noticed the bear had broken into his garage where he kept his trash. RP also noticed that the bear had broken into their vehicles and eaten some sunflower seeds. WL 544 came out and did a site inspection. WL544 did notice a bird feeder but the RP said the bear had never gotten into the bird feeder. WL544 advised that he should take it in until after thanksgiving. WL544 decided to set a trap since the bear was rewarded with food in the RP’s garage. RP believes bear is being attracted due to neighbors trash.
END

WL 367 Met Alamosa PD officer out at residence. Hazed bear with double ball non lethal. Bear went further up tree. Bear appeared to be about 100 lbs. Residence appeared to be unoccupied but notified neighbor of bear presence.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials
Comments:
There have been several incidents over the last few weeks. The bear has successfully broken into a Jeep soft top, and a garage window. It is reported to be approaching other sheds and garages while looking into the windows. The bear has been run off but comes back. Bear comes back every trash day. Last seen on Thursday April 30th. RP believes it will be back tomorrow. RP would appreciate a call from a wildlife officer to know we are taking it seriously.

WL283 did a site visit and gave suggestions on limiting future contacts with bears by fortifying the shed that they keep their trash in. The RP said that they have a bear proof trash can being delivered soon.
Bear killed two Rams and injuries several more. Unknown how many will survive. WS waited for bear. Bear was shot. Unable to find bear.

Rp has seen yearling bear in area multiple times. Tried to haze it off by approaching and yelling and bear growled. Bear appeared afraid. Rp said they lived outside of city limits. Advised to try sub-lethals and dropped off a pack of rubber buck and gave instructions on how to use. While dropping ammo off, saw bear two houses down eating trash and gazed off.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials
Comments: RP's mother contacted CSP Dispatch who contacted ON CALL Wildlife Officer HOLDER #754. DWM HOLDER contacted RP by telephone and RP was whispering in tent concerned about bear being aggressive because he could hear it walking around outside the tent. DWM HOLDER traveled to Monument Lake did a site inspection and talked to two male individuals both camping with females. Verbal education on food or hygene materials in tent, sexual activity (discussion with males), where to sleep in tent (away from sides), vehicle windows/doors, food storage etc. Business cards given and DWM HOLDER stayed in area until daylight.

Comments: RP is owner of Pagosa Seed and Nursery. Stated that bear has caved in plastic fencing several times in back of nursery and fed on plants and bathed in water trough (tracks around trough). Has tried ammonia soaked rags on fence with no luck. 325 advised to install a hot wire above fence and empty trough daily. Several bears noted in previous incidents in the same vicinity.

RP called and wanted me to know that a bear was on his neighbor's porch early in the morning.  I went to the neighbor's residence and spoke to him about the bear.  He showed me a video of the bear rolling around an aluminum trash can that was outside on his porch.  

The man told me he shot into the ground a couple of times to scare the bear away.

Advised him to bring his hummingbird and chipmunk feeders inside.  Gave him 'bear aware' materials.  Told him to call me if the situation changes.

Went to the neighbors in the area and left 'bear aware' literature.

Bear was trying to enter home through dog door, trying to get to dog food. Wildlife 186 skinned out bear and donated meat. Refer to photos.

Complaint Type: Non-Food Property Damage , Sighting , Aggressive Behavior

Comments:
RP called you report that a bear keeps coming around and does not seem to be afraid of people.  Officer asked RP if the had any food items, bird feeders or other attractants outside.  RP said trash was in the garage, they did have hummingbird feeders out and a grill.  Told RP to remove hummingbird feeders and clean grill. Gave her other recommendations on deterrents.  RP said that neighbor puts out corn and other items for the turkeys, but did not know the address.
Responded to the area to look for neighbor’s address. Spoke wit RPs husband.  He pointed out the address, but did want neighbor to know.  Asked that officer wait to contact neighbor. WL526

On 09/28/2020 Wildlife 261 received a phone call from Chaffee County dispatch stating a bear incident had occurred at the location above. WL 261 was close by and met the RP at the location. The RP stated that he just sat down under a tree to have lunch and a nap when he saw a sow and 2 cubs. He stated that the sow walked towards him but did not display any aggressive behavior or make any grunts or popping noises. He stated that he then threw his lunch towards the bear and ran out of the area as fast as he could. WL 261 informed the RP that the sow and cubs were probably along the river to escape the heat of the day and would probably be moving out of the area sometime shortly after sunset. WL 261 went down to the are where the RP saw the bear but it was on a piece of heavily wooded private property that WL 261 could not find permission to enter. Due to its location to a city owned trail WL 261 put bear activity in the area signs up at the the nearest trail head.

RP had several bears in yard due to large crab apple tree. One bear was in tree. SMSO was unable to respond. WL382 responded. Small bear ran off as WL382 arrived. Large bear in apple tree. WL382 fired two bean bag rounds. One while bear in tree, second as bear was running away. Provided deterrent rounds to RP. Several days later, RP called to inquire if WL382 had "brought in people to exterminate the bears" as RP had only seen a large bear in area and no bears were coming into yard.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set , Pyrotechnics
Comments: Bear went into chicken coop and ate 13 chickens. Still have 4 chickens left but are keeping them in the house. Bear ripped wood door off chicken coop, visible claw marks and teeth marks on wood door.  Bear scat located next to coop. Set trap on 6/8 and gave GD forms and 5 rounds of rubber buck. Told Rp if he was going to keep chickens should put up electric fencing around the coop area to deter bear activity. Set trap on 6/8/2020. Caught in trap on evening of 6/8/2020.

WL124: Estes PD notifed me of a bear walking near downtown midday. When I got on scene, bear already left and ran up into the nearby neighborhood. I spoke with the police officer who saw it and said it was the same bear seen the Tuesday before near the Birch Ruins open space.

WL 261 received a message from the area office stating the RP had a bear incident at her address. WL 261 contacted the RP and discovered that a bear had climbed up into her large dumb bin in her backyard which was filled with non-food waste. She stated that it was a large adult bear and she had discovered the bear had been on her property due to security cameras that she has set up at her house. WL 261 asked the RP to inform her neighbors in the area that they have seen a bear and to put away all attractants at night. The RP agreed. She also stated that herself and several others in the neighborhood use a large dump bin that is bear resistant for their food scraps. WL 261 thanked her and asked her to keep using it. WL 261 also informed the RP that he would be in the area at night and in the early morning to try and haze the bear if it comes back. The RP stated that was ok and if CPW needs to set a trap for it in the future, that we can on her property.

RP stated that a young bear broke the door of his chicken coop and took  3 chickens on night of 7/5. Fixed door, has 4 chickens left. Bear returned on 7/6, RP shot with bean bag round and bear ran off. RP not concerned with chickens he has left. 325 issued rubber rounds.

No further response as of now.

WL541 received a report from the RP that a large dark brown colored bear with a green ear tag in the left ear was in Tucker Gulch around 7:00pm.  It matched the description of the bear that had been hanging around Tucker Gulch and hitting trash cans within the neighborhood since last week.   
WL545, WL546 and WL541 responded to try to haze the bear.

The bear was followed around Golden and hazed with noise and lights until it crossed over Highway 58 and was lost in the vegetation surrounding Clear Creek.

Original call from CSP dispatch was of a Bear sighting on 27 Rd. and Club Drive.  Multiple calls to both CSP Dispatch and the CPW Grand Junction Office came in through the day with sightings around the Bookcliff Golf Course area.  At approximately 1730 I received a call from CSP Dispatch that the sub-adult Black Bear was in the back yard at 754 27 RD Grand Junction.  Wildlife Officers 442, 447, and 441 attempted to tree the bear at that location, and than in the a joining Golf Course to no avail.  The bear would not tree and continued to run eventually crossing 27 Rd. to the West and was last seen at 755 Continental Ct.  The decision was made at that time to let the bear calm down and attempt to trap it if it was sighted again. The bear was reported to  the CPW  Office as being photographed by a door cam early on the 08/18/20 at 753 Centauri Dr.   
 " recorded as a separate event" There have been no further sightings or reports.

WL 186 Received a call from Colorado State Patrol Stating there was a bear inside a resident along with a female and her three kids. WL 186 responded immediately to the call.  Upon arrival Officer Foster contacted Emily Hill. She stated the bear got into her house through a open door she had just opened for her dog to go out and use the restroom. The bear entered the house and went through the kitchen and broke window latches and plant pots trying to get out of the house. Luckily the door was still open and it exited the same door it came in through. The whole time the bear was in the house her kids were locked in their bedroom and she was upstairs.

WL 186 Set a trap and informed her to call him if the bear returns.

Refer to picture of the description of the bear
