I Wildlife Officer Clayton BonDurant responded to a sighting of some bears behind the RPs residence.  After waiting, I was able to haze off a larger male bear that was in the alley.  The mother and 2 cubs that has been in town for last 2 months was in nearby tree, most likely staying away from the male.

RP reported a bear hanging around a vacant property for two days going in large circles.  Krall responded and found the bear lying under a tree on the reported property.  Krall approached the bear which got up and loped off and left the property.  Bear appeared to be in good condition and no odd behavior.

While Krall was talking to the RP the bear returned and began going in a large circle.  It completed the same circle in the same path at least a dozen times.  Bear seemed alert with no vision issues.  Krall recorded a video of the bear and sent the video to Karen Fox, Mary the new vet, and supervisor Mike Trujillo.  While waiting for feedback from Fox and the vet, Krall called Trujillo.  Trujillo told Krall to kill the bear.  He did not ask any further questions.  As Krall was about to euthanize the bear the vet responded that based on the video, she did not believe the bear had any neurological or disease issues.  The vet suggested that it may be a sow that had lost her cubs based on the behavior.  Krall asked her advice on Tranquilizer vs euthanize.  She recommended tranquilizer but said ultimately it was Krall’s decision. 

Krall called Trujillo, who allowed Krall to tranquilizer the bear.  Krall darted the bear at 10 yards using 2cc of Nalmed from bottle 2019-04-11.  The bear was immobilized in about 5 minutes.

Krall inspected the bear which showed no obvious signs of injuries or disease.  The bear was lactating.  The bears age appeared to be about 4-6, closer to 4.  Body condition was fair.  No cubs had been seen in the area for two days, but a sow and two cubs had been reported in the area earlier.  There were no reports of the sow and Cubs causing problems, just sightings.

Krall called Trujillo and asked if he could tag and release on site.  Trujillo said I could release on site, but not to tag or make a report.  Krall asked how to account for 2cc of drug and policy.  Trujillo allowed Krall to use white ear tags (SE 384), since no issues with bear.  Krall gave the bear 4cc atemeprozol and after a bit of time the bear wandered of.  As of 06/24 the bear has not returned.  Krall did a thorough search of the property and could not find any sign of cubs.  

On 06/21 Krall met with Trujillo in Westcliffe to get a taser.  Trujillo told Krall that he had seen that behavior many times in animals that lost their young.

Comments: Heather called and reported a bear who got into her camper on 5-25-2020 and the night of 5-27-2020. The bear obtained dog food from inside the camper. RP was in the camper sleeping with dog. RP woke up to dog barking, had bang pots and pans to get bear to leave. The bear was within 20 ft of her and dog while inside the camper. The morning of 5-28-2020 RP saw bear outside and seemed to act aggressive toward her dog. RP described bear as large (300 lb), black phase bear.  Clayton Bondurant set bear trap on 5-29-2020. On 6-6-2020 RP calls Leon Martinez that bear is in the trap. Leon Martinez responds to RP and finds a Cinnamon phase bear, approximately 200 lb, with a dark brown face and front.  Officers released the bear on-site being that the bear in trap was not the target bear. Bear was hazed with rubber buckshot and a bean bag.

Officer Holder responded to RP who said she thought a bear had tried to get into her house.  When Officer Holder arrived he found paw prints on a closed and secure glass window.  There was a hummingbird feeder hanging from the roof directly above it.  The bear was most likely raising up on the window to get the feeder down.  Performed a site inspection and asked the RP to take down the hummingbird feeders around the house.  Advised to keep the doors and windows shut and latched and to secure the trash in the garage or with a ratchet strap.  The RP has my direct number and I asked her to call if she had anymore conflicts with the bear.

Same bear as previous calls in town. Bean bagged the bear.
Collbran Marshal has also hazed this bear. It only is eating trash in town at this point.

Officer Sent FYI
RP called to report possible bear activity. Last night, his dogs were barking but he did not know why. This morning, he found his bee hives knocked over. The RP was calling to ask what we would do when he shot it. The bee hives are a hobby for the RP and he did not have the hives fenced off or protected in any way. This is the first time any sort of bear activity has occurred  on his property. I recommended using deterrents to ward off the bear and reminded him if the hive is unprotected, the bear will continue to be rewarded. I recommended setting up an electric fence and using ammonia as a scent deterrent. I also recommended setting up motion lights so that he can see the hives at night and to use noise to haze the bear in the future. I also recommended using rubber buck shot if the bear comes back. I reminded him that he wants to scare the bear and that by using negative reinforcement it will associate people with the bad experience and avoid interactions in the future. The RP refused education materials because he "has lived there for 12 years and knows what to do".  LB
Officer Olson called and discussed with the RP the laws pertaining to when a bear can be legally removed for causing damage and offered to drop by some rubber buckshot for hazing. Officer Olson stopped by the residence later that afternoon and issued some rubber buckshot and discussed the situation further. The RP has no other obvious attractants on his property. J Olson #088

Complaint Type: Food Source Property Damage , Non-Food Property Damage

Comments:
This report is to document a meeting with the owners of Ramon’s Mexican restaurant to cover what they needed to do to reduce the bear activity at their business. CPW and SF PD have fielded multiple calls at this location on bears in their dumpster. DWM Gallegos also brought his father to interpret in case they were more comfortable speaking Spanish. 
Items covered:
1. Majority of the lids are broken on bear proof dumpster making it ineffective. It needs to be fixed.
2. In the interim, chains or cables need to be used in combination with a come-along to tightly close lids.
3. Electric fencing was discussed, and construction options using existing enclosure was also discussed.
4. Potential fines for inaction were covered, and how DWM Gallegos would much rather Ramon’s put money into improving their enclosure instead of paying fines.
They were very receptive, and agreed to implement these recommendations.

On June 16th an adult bear came to the RP's house and got into bird feeders which were on the RP's back porch. The next night the bear returned, but the RP had removed the bird feeders. The bear found a nearby bird box and ate the eggs from the bird nest that was inside. 

The RP contacted WL 261 on 06/25/2020. WL 261 informed the RP to remove all attractants from the outside of this house. Which he stated he did. WL 261 also informed the RP that he would deliver rubber buckshot to him to haze the bear. On 06/26/2020 WL 261 delivered buckshot to the RP's house.

RP met with 325 to show him where a large brown colored bear has been consistently bedding for the day. Bear stays all day in very thick willows next to a golf course pond at the corner of Cloudcap Ave and Park Ave. RP sees it enter the willows in the morning and exit late in the evening. Somewhat concerned with its proximity to pedestrians and golfers who have no idea that it's there. Likely one of several bears getting into dumpsters in the area. 325 hung "Bear Active..." sign  on a post at a walking trail next to the pond.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set
Comments: Bear came to home night of 05/13 and tore up motorcycle seat and also damaged the back of a car. Bear apparently looked into RP’s daughter’s window.  RP said she feeds her dog outside in his kennel so there is usually food outside. RP was advised to take dogs food bowl inside after feeding, and to secure all attractants. RP was open to borrowing an unwelcome mat.  WL324 followed up with RP, who voiced safety concerns with the bear getting into the house, children playing outside etc.  324 made site visit, and set a trap on 5/14, and picked the trap up on 5/17.  According to the RP the bear had not been back.  On 5/18 the RP called 324 and reported that the bear had returned the night before around midnight.  Sabrina contacted A15 office requesting the bear be run out of here by dogs or relocated. Office advised her that is not normal procedure. 324 forwarded the call to the district officer. 326 tried twice on 5/18 and once on 5/19 to contact Sabrina on phone. No answer and voicemail not set up. 326 made contact in afternoon on 5/19. Will do a site visit on 5/20. 326 did a site visit and slope to Sabrina’s husband. Provided info on electric unwelcome mats. Advised we don’t trap bears just because they are around. He said he has access to a plug on fence charger and will make some electron unwelcome mats. Nothing further at this time.

Comments:
RP stated that the bear came by and was sniffing around the windows.  She thought the bear was trying to get into the house.  She was worried since her older mother lives in the house and could get hurt.  The RP stated that the bear gets into her trash most weeks.  The RP stated that the bear got into her house 3 weeks ago and again last year.  WL 524 provided a site inspection and educational materials. WL 524 set a pepper barrel.  He also told her to remove the 4 hummingbird feeders, the 4 seed feeders, and to clean up all the peanuts left out for the birds.

Pulled pepper barrel 10/18/2020

On 8/20/2020 Wildlife 261 got a phone call from Chaffee County Dispatch that there was a bear incident that had taken place across the Arkansas River from the Salida East put in. WL 261 contacted the RP and the RP stated that a bear had been to campsite three times that night and had got into his cooler and trash that he had outside. He stated that the bear started coming into camp at 3:00 AM and come back two other times by 3:30 AM. WL 261 instructed the the RP to collect his trash and food and lock them into his vehicle and remove anything that had a scent from the tent and lock that up as well. The RP informed WL 261 that he did not feel comfortable going outside to collect the trash and food, and did not have a car to lock the food and trash in. The RP stated all he had was a mountain bike. WL 261 informed the RP to make as much noise as possible if the bear came back, and informed the RP that WL 261 would be making a site visit as soon as he got ready. The RP stated that he understood.  As WL 261 was getting ready the bear returned. WL 261 arrived on scene and could not find the bear. WL 261 contacted the RP who was outside his tent. WL 261 informed the RP to collect the trash and food and put it as far away from his tent as possible in case the bear came back, since the RP had no way of securing it. The RP agreed and did so. He also informed the RP to remove any thing with a scent from the tent which the RP stated he already had. WL 261 walked the river bank an approximate 200 yards from the tent in the direction the RP stated the bear had went and found food wraps and bear scat but no bear. WL 261 educated the RP on the importance of putting bear attractants away or in a tree at night and he understood, he also told the RP to make a lot of noise if the bear came back with pots and pans which the RP had. WL 261 also informed the RP to contact him if the bear came back that night. The RP stated that he would be leaving in the morning and would not be staying another night in the same location.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials
Comments: WL 265 responded and did a site inspection on 7/7 at 2100.  Bear got into trash and was in the duck pen.  RP showed me a picture of the bear and it was a black color phase yearling.  Bear also got into the trash.  Recommended putting electric fence around the duck and rabbit pen, securing trash with a ratchet strap, and borrowing a paintball gun from a friend to haze the bear.  Gave a Living with Bears pamphlet for further recommendations on how to minimize conflicts with bears in the future.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials
Comments:
First actual call to CPW about this bear that has been hitting trash daily in Eagle for over 4 weeks. All other info on this bear has been through facebook or word of mouth.
Bear was seen during the day going through RP's trash which was left outside.  RP will now keep trash inside garage from now on.  I patrolled the areas where the bear has been seen throughout the weekend but unable to find.  While patrolling, had over 40 homes bring their trash cans inside from now on but most neighborhoods in Eagle have over 75%  of each street with trash outside in unsecured containers.

RP called to report a bear that he had been having issues with for about a month. RP said a bear was consistently getting into their trash and they had a dumpster with a locking bar and plastic lid. RP said bear was becoming more aggressive because since they started taking their trash off site it started coming close to their vehicle and left a paw print on the window. WL544 offered to come out and take a look but suggested that he remove any attractants that were possibly bringing bear in. 

On August 8th WL544 did a site visit. RP said that they were not having any more issues since they started taking the trash to another location and making sure there were not any attractants. RP said that they did have a freezer full of meat in the barn but they kept the door closed and a radio on. WL544 did not observe any attractants on the property and it was clean with little trash. WL544 let the RP know that if he started having issues again to let WL544 know. 

END

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials
Comments:
No Further Response Needed. 
RP was woken up at 4:30am Saturday to his chickens screaming. He and his dog went outside and saw a bear in the coop actively eating his chickens. The RP's dog  started barking and running at the bear and the bear charged the dog. RP and dog ran back into the house and closed the door. RP s stated the bear was on his porch and after 10 minutes it ran west off the property. The house is right off of Memmen Open Space where the bear came from. 

WLO 549 was notified on Sunday 10/4 of the incident and called RP back. 549 stated that the chickens and other attractants like trash brought the bear into the yard and that the RP would need to bear proof the house and chicken coop. 549 asked if the bear was trying to get into the house, the RP stated that it was not. 549 suggested electric fencing, ammonia soaked rags and a radio on inside the coop. RP wanted CPW to relocate the bear. 549 told RP that he lives in bear habitat and that he would be dealing with bears as long as he has attractants so removing the bear would not fix his problem. 549 told RP that he had the right to shoot the bear if it was actively attacking his chickens as long as he lives in unincorporated Douglas County and there were no firearm restrictions. 549 also offered to do a site visit and RP agreed. 

The next day (10/5), WLO 549 went to 232 Ash Ave for a site visit. She noticed that the trash was out and that they had not cleaned the backyard up from the other night. 549 took photos of the yard and damage (see attached photos). 549 told RP to secure the coop and maybe put electric fencing on the border fence, she also mentioned un-welcome mats and ammonia soaked rags along the fence. RP mentioned he and his wife moved there in February from Texas and was not familiar with living in bear country. 549 asked RP if he wanted education material on  how to bear proof his property and he was interested in that offer. 549 sent bear proof/ education material to RP's email. 
-WLO549

On 07/31/2020 Wildlife 261 was contacted by the RP. She stated that she works for several bed and breakfasts in Garfield and one of the ones she works for has home security cameras that video taped an injured bear the night before.  She stated that it had an injured back leg and she shared the video with WL 261.  After watching the video WL 261 believed that the injury was not life threatening to the bear. The RP told WL 261 that neighbors in the area have told her that the bear is tipping over their garbage at night, but she has not had any issues with that so far. WL 261 educated the RP on putting away bear attractants at night at all of her places of work, and offered Rubber Buckshot to haze the bear if it was seen by the RP again. The RP stated that she did not have a 12 gauge shotgun, but stated that she would ask her neighbors if they did so that WL 261 could get them some Rubber Buckshot.

The RP informed WL 261 that the bear was seen again on camera  on 08/01/2020.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set , Hazed , Relocated

Large amounts of trash and unsecured coolers were in the camp and in the bed of the truck. CG hosts called on 7/27 to say the bear came back to Blue Lake CG the previous night and got more coolers. Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set , Hazed , Relocated
Comments:
Sow and cub have been visiting the Poudre Canyon Fire station 2.  Bears have been trying to walk into bay doors of the fire house,fire crews would try to haze the bears away but the bears  would not leave.  Bears climb on to vehicles  while the owner was in the back of the truck sleeping.  Bears tried to break into a camper shell of a fire  crews truck. The bears are showing up in the middle of the day and at night.  Bob has bean bagged the bears on  8/25, they moved off but did not seam to be bothered with the hazing.  At this site wild land fire crew are camping on site the bears are nosing around tents at night.  WL 186  and Bob have instructed crews to keep food locked in trucks. The bears are showing no sign of fear towards humans.  On 8/26 WL 186 patrolled the area but did not see the bears.
A trap is set at this address, trap was set on 8/28 by WL186. Trap was pulled on 9/01.

WL 186 was contacted by Bob on 9/5 regarding the sow and cub back around the fire station.  On the night of  9/4 the cub pulled the out the window screens and was pushing on the windows of the building.  Fire fighter scared the bears off.  Both bears were getting into the back of trucks and pulling on truck topper windows.

On 9/5 WL 186 set the trap again for the sow and cub.  On the morning of 9/6 the sow and cod  were trapped.

Sow : Green ear tag 342
Cub (female): Green ear tag 713
.75 cc NalMed, 20-A04-NMA-02
Reversal: 1.5 Apam

Sow and cub returned to the fire station and upper canyon area (Rustic) around the 14th - 15th of September.  Bears are continuing to visit the dumpsters at the fire station, but are not getting any reward.  WL 186/184 have been  in contact with the fire crews educating them on keep food locked up in vehicles and in the building.   The bears have been climbing into the back of parked trucks , they haven’t broken any windows out or have not figured out how to open vehicle doors.
Since the bears returned CPW personal have been patrolling the area at nights.  Personal have deployed bean bag rounds at the sow and cub and have struck the Bears. On the morning of 9/29 WL 186 deployed his taser striking the sow, which was standing on top of the dumper.

One, possibly two bears have gotten into small apiary protected by electric fencing. Bear has also gotten into other garden areas. RP would like a game warden to come take a look at the damage. 
328 - RP advised as how to improve electric fence around beehives. Also advised property owner about protecting garden and chickens. Provided RP with beanbag round and bear spray.  
On June 1st Wildlife officer 328 visited property owner and provided him with more rubber slugs. Property owner had not had any more problems.
Bear got in backyard and broke fence and tried to get in duck pen.  Gave the RP rubber buckshot, advised to electrify the duck pen, secure all trash, close door on garage etc

WL124: Received a call from a person watching someone’s home that a bear was in the chicken coop and killed some of the chickens. Bear was gone upon arrival. Bear killed 4 chickens this morning and killed one chicken the previous morning. One chicken was still alive with injuries to the back and head. Collected the chickens. Advised RP of game damage and she replied she believes the chickens are pets. Provided advice to lock remaining chickens inside at night.

Sow was hit and 2 cubs were orphaned.  Both cubs were caught and sent to rehab I silt.  Will later be tagged when released.

Comments: Cap K Ranch. Bear broke into barn and got into grain. RP boarded up door and parked tractor in front of door. Has seen large black colored bear around ranch frequently but not sure if that was the one that broke in. Issued rubber buckshot.

RP owns a small farm in Howard, Ring-A-Ding Farms.  I know the RP and have worked with him regarding bear problems in the past. 

The RP told me some people living in a camper trailer on the farm left their car window unrolled and a bear got into the car.  He told me there were beverages in the car and the bear got into them.  

RP also told me one of the tenants told him a bear got into their chickens.  I asked him if it was anytime soon and he told me it was not.  I told him to have the tenant who farms call me and I could give information on how to better secure the coop.  I recommended electric fence. and electrified poultry netting.

The RP was good with allowing bear hunters on the property . That evening I made contact with two bear hunters (Ves and Chance Gulliford) and contacted another two (Trish and Ray Morishini) the following day.  The hunters were going to contact Ring to try to harvest the bear.

Drove past the farm which is surrounded by 10' high fencing on 9/19/2020 to see if the tenants who raise the chickens and turkeys was there.  The gate  to the farm was closed and I did not see anyone.  As of 9/19/2020 the  tenants who have the chickens and farm animals haven't called.

No further response needed.
Officers McKee and Dodd were patrolling in the Rainbow Falls area off of County Road 49 that evening. Saw a black bear, brown in color approximately 200 pounds, Marauding through an unattended campsite.  A UTV trailer had been left open and trash and all camp food had been left unattended in camp.  Officers hazed the bear by yelling and use of a bean bag round.  Camping in bear country brochures were provided to campers along that stretch.  Information and a notice was left at the campsite by Officer Dodd.  On the way out, officers ran into the parties associated with that camp. They stated they would clean everything up and that they were heading out that evening (maroon Chevy occupied by five CLP552)
Officer Mckee contacted Fanta with US forest service. He was made aware of the situation and was going to contact other USFS  employees that cover that area so all parties could keep an eye out.
End of report
JM

Upon arrival the bear was gone.  A crank style wing window was on the porch intact.  No glass was broken and there was no evidence of prying of the window frame or window itself.  Bear got into kitchen items at the address.  The house had been vacant for several days/weeks prior.  No people were in the house.  The bear was interrupted by the local "fix-it" guy going in to winterize the house.  I deployed an electric mat in front of the window because it could only be boarded up by the "fix-it" guy.  I contacted the Natelborg's on 9/29/20 and confirmed permission to leave the Electric Mat on their porch for the time being.  Ken wanted me to trap and move/kill the sow and cubs .

The bear was found dead in the middle of the Dome Rock trail by the Rp. The bear had a large wound on it's left leg, right shoulder, and the chest cavity was open so much I could see several ribs. Cause of death was unknown

On, 08/08/2020, I, Wildlife Officer Scott Murdoch, was on routine patrol along the Khuester Rd.  While on patrol, I drove down North Trail Circle to talk with landowners that live along the road.  I occasionally meet with these landowners to continue a positive relationship with them and CPW.  

While patrolling, I pulled into the address of 13854 North Trail Circle, (see above owner and parcel ID).  This address belongs to Russell (Rusty) W. Andrews (04/13/1958) CID:186200051.  I pulled into the driveway (Photo 1) and near the cabin observed a wood board covered in corn, birdseed, watermelon, a bucket of grease, and a tin of dog food (Photos 2-4).  It was clear that the food was left to intentionally feed bears.  I looked up Andrews on the Colorado Parks and Wildlife License database and he did not have any bear hunting licenses for 2020.  I also obtained Andrews phone number ((303) 944-4953).

While at the property there was a female with 2 children.  I spoke to her and she said Rusty was not there.  I asked if he was going to be by soon.  She said perhaps tomorrow.

Later, at approximately 5:02 pm on 8/8/2020, I called Andrews and left him a message asking him to call me back.  At 9:27 am on 8/9/2020, I received a call from Andrews.  I recognized his voice as Andrews.  I informed him that I found his pile of food that he had been leaving out for the bears.  I informed him that he cannot intentionally feed bears.  I gave him a verbal warning (warning required for the initial violation as required by statute) for violation of 33-6-131 CRS as amended:  Did knowingly and unlawfully place food in the open with the intent of luring a wild bear to such food.  

Andrews acknowledged that it was not a good idea to feed the bears and understood the changes that feeding results in with bear behavior.  I asked Andrews if he was planning on hunting over the bait.  Andrews said that he has chased wildlife all over the hills in the past and he has wounded animals and was hoping by baiting that he wouldn't wound a bear if it came in.  I explained the bear-baiting statutes and the stiff consequences if he continued his behavior.  He said he would remove the bait.  I asked if there was any more around his property.  He said no.

This has been entered into CrimeIntel also.  Case 087-04-2020 Officer Scott Murdoch.

Wildlife 261 received a phone call from Chaffee County Sheriff's Office stating that a bear was getting into trash near the RP's address. WL 261 then contacted the RP who stated that his kids were out riding bikes when they saw a bear sniffing trashcans in the neighborhood. The RP stated that the bear was still in the area. WL 261 responded to the scene but the bear had left the area and headed North back to the other side of the Arkansas River. The RP told WL 261 that they bear had not got in to any trashcans that night, but on the night of 06/21/2020 it had been into several trashcans on the street. WL 261 asked the RP if he could let his neighbors know that a bear was in the area and to try to put away all bear attractants at night, including using their bear resistant trash containers or not putting the trash out until trash day. The RP agreed. WL 261 also informed the RP that he would do late evening and early morning patrols in the area to try and haze the bear if given the opportunity. WL 261 also told the RP to call if he sees the bear at any point after this. The RP agreed.

RP has encountered bears on the patio 10 ft from the door to the house  and has run them off by yelling at them and acting aggressively toward them. 

Others in the valley have had bear issues but do not call trying to protect the bears. RP has lived in the valley for just under 1 year. RP asked about when it is legal to shoot a bear but suggested that was a last resort. RP understood that relocation is highly likely to fail. RP was given information about establishing his "territory" with the bears but that bears will persist in the environment around his home. 

Unwelcome mats, motion detector with a radio, electric fencing, rubber buck and a pepper barrel are all planned to attempt to realign bear behavior.

Ken Caryl Ranger, Matt Oven, responded as CPW  officers were on another call.  Homeowners had left vehicles unlocked and had a backpack full of granola bars. The bear got into the vehicle pulled out the backpack and pulled it down the street where it ate food out of the pack. No damage was on the vehicle.  Homeowners were advised to keep all attractants out of the vehicle and to lock their vehicles.  Homeowners had also had bears in  trash a few times over the last couple weeks. They were advised to keep all trash locked.  
Education material is sent out to Ken Caryl residents every year.  
In addition, on July 7, 2020 an educational blast went out to this neighborhood that included a next-door posting, local Ken Caryl media sites, their local Facebook, and their e-news.  This release specifically talked about removing all trash cans until morning of pick up and removing all valuables from cars and locking them up.
A bear packet will be mailed directly to this homeowner on Monday.
JM

Complaint Type: Food Source Property Damage , Non-Food Property Damage , Sighting
Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials
Comments: CSP called DWM Gallegos about 2:30 a.m., and advised that a homeowner had shot and killed a bear in his house above Creede. They also advised that they had a Mineral County Deputy in route. DWM Gallegos called the RP en route to advise that he was on his way. Once there the RP told DWM Gallegos that he had a bear get into his trash the previous night. He loaded his 45 Long Colt lever action rifle in case the bear tried to get in his house. The bear ended up leaving. The following morning he picked up his trash can and put it in his shed. Early on the morning of the 24th he heard a noise in the living room, which is adjacent to his bedroom. He grabbed his rifle, and found the bear in his living room. He fired a total of 9 times, killing the bear with a shot to the head on his last shot. He then called 911. The bear had entered through what appeared to be an open window. An additional open window was found over the kitchen table. The bear was removed from the house by the Deputy and DWM Gallegos. Mr. Williams was advised that he was within his legal right to protect life at that point, and satisfied the notification requirement, so no laws were broken. He was advised that they needed to adapt to living in bear country when they came out to Colorado, by not waiting until the bear got their trash to store it properly and shut windows at night. A “Living with Bears” brochure was given to him.

Officer Chrisman found the camp to be clean and the trash locked up. The RP said they are not allowing any food outside and has had experience with bears at the camp in the past. Officer Chrisman gave the RP rubber buckshot and made sure he knew proper shot placement.

On 09/07/2020 Wildlife 261 received a call from Chaffee County that a bear incident was occurring. WL 261 contacted the RP and the RP stated that he saw two healthy bear cubs run up a tree at the location listed above. WL 261 responded to the location and discovered a sow with two cubs up the tree. WL 261 contacted the homeowners around that area that were home and requested that they limit the amount of time they spend outside near and the tree and asked not the publicly share picture of the bears until after they leave so large crowds do not gather near the tree and force the bears to stay up the tree longer than needed. All homeowners agreed. WL 261 informed the homeowners that CPW was just going to let the bears remain in the tree, until tonight when the bears should come down on their own and head back towards the river. WL 261 remained across the street monitoring the tree for 1 hour after. No groups of people formed near the tree. After another call that day about the cubs being at the base of the tree WL 261, WL 262, and WL 270 took turns staying on scene until the bears left the tree at 2015 hours and went towards the river

On September 21 at approximately 10:45 PM Officer Mckee was doing patrols around the Ken Caryl neighborhood where there had been active bear activity.  She observed trash cans in front of the house of 6 Periwinkle Which had been tipped over and trash had been scattered.  Marks on the trashcan and scattered trash and bags were all consistent with bear.  Officer McKee hung a door hanger at the residence to let the homeowners know that they could not place their  trash out the night before.
Officer McKee returned on October 8, 2020 to speak with the homeowners Chad and Christie.  Christie was in the car with her daughter backing out of the driveway .  Christie stated that Chad had picked the trash up the next morning.  She also stated that both of them saw the door hanger.  She stated that they had learned their lesson and that they would not be placing trash out the night before again.  Officer McKee issued a verbal warning and left the scene.
J Mckee

Complaint Type: Food Source Property Damage , Sighting , Attack , Aggressive Behavior
Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials
Comments: WL124: RP was Urgent care worker who reported they treated someone who was attacked by a bear earlier that morning. I went to the Manor RV park campsite #80 to speak to the victim, Howard Terkins (DOB 03/20/1956), and investigate. The victim said he heard a noise near his truck  between 4:30-5am. He exited his camper and a bear charged him, knocking him on the ground and scratched him on his chest and stomach. The bear was described as large and brown in color. The victim did not report the incident to authorities. Upon investigation of the scene, victim left a bag of dog food in the bed of his truck that the bear was getting into. There was also a paw print on the truck that was a size consistent to a cub. I spoke with the Manor RV general manager and recommended a trap to be set and they declined. Advised the victim and the Manor RV employees. One employee said a brown sow with two black cubs have been frequenting the rv park.

Bob was doing fire Patrol in Mandatory evacuation area of the Cameron Peak Fire.  He found a camp trailer that was broken into by a bear along with another camper that had multiple bear prints on it and damage to the trailer skirting.  Bear was able to get food and trash from inside the camper.  On September 9 Foster was also in the area doing routine patrol’s and did not observe damage to the trailer.  Damage was done between the 9th and 11th of September.Bob notified Foster on September 11th regarding  damage to the trailer.
A green ear tag bear had been seen in the area.  A trap was set on the afternoon of the 9/12 after a site visit by Foster.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set , Euthanized
Comments: Sandra called concerned about a large bear that was using a storm drain that had openings in her yard and alley, which the bear was frequently using.  I visited the site, and advised about noise, light, and using scent deterrents.  The bear would growl and make noise when anyone would approach the entrance to the storm drain.  Also provided advise suggestions about closing the storm drain entrances.  Officer Gallowich unsuccessfully attempted to haze the bear on multiple occasions.  The bear continued to use the storm drain, and a trap was set on 8/2/2020.  The trap was then pulled on 8/7/2020.  The bear returned that night and broke through a wooden fence again to get to the storm drain. A trap was again set on 8/8/2020 and the bear was caught at 12:30 AM on the 8/10/2020.  The bear was euthanized and has seal # 41104

Complaint Type: Food Source Property Damage , Non-Food Property Damage

Comments:
NO Further Response Needed. WL544 got a call on June 19th at approximately 7:00pm from Colorado State Patrol that Commerce City Police Department had a bear in a tree at 6675 Birch St. commerce city CO. WL 544 responded with WL546, and WL542.  The bear was eventually Tranquilized at approximately 11:44 pm, put into a trap and relocated to better bear habitat. The bear was released the morning of June 20th at approximately 4:00 am. The bear was based with director fund taser cartridges and bean bag rounds upon release. A bear with similar characteristics was observed in  Fort Lupton earlier this year traveling south East along the River. No previous documented history of aggressive behavior. 
END
Durango office received multiple reports of a bear hit by a car on the side of Hwy 160, West of the Florida river crossing. WL 326 responded and picked up the bear. Bear had ear tags, blue 826.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set
Comments: Bowers claimed attack but untouched.....8 feet distance closest.

RP was woken up by his dog barking and a noise. He came outside and saw a bear by his shed. Tried to scare it away with poppers (firework poppers) and the bear was not scared. RP ran into the house and got a pistol. Shot three or four times into a hillside above the bear. The bear then ran off up the hill. No blood was found or evidence that the bear was hit. His shed door was broken off. There was trash and birdseed in the shed. This was the second time the bear was here and messing with the shed. WL283 gave advise on how to protect the shed.

Complaint Type: Food Source Property Damage , Non-Food Property Damage
Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set , Euthanized
Comments:
RPs woke up this morning to find a screen ripped off the window, that was open. Food was eaten on the counter in the kitchen.

WL 287 set a trap and found brownish cinnamon colored hairs on the window. The bear ate a bunch of fudge the RP made and a bag of Doritos on the kitchen table. It does not appear that it ventured past the table.

Trap was set and a large 335 lbs. male bear was caught and euthanized.

Comments: WL124: I was near the town hall building and observed a large brown bear in the dumpster enclosure. Bear was hazed away with one round of bean bag from the downtown area and into nearby open space property. Same bear that had been seen frequenting the area midday.

Comments: WL324 received a call that the large bear that has been seen throughout the neighborhood and shows no fear of humans or dogs had been seen on the neighboring property looking in windows and looking for food. RPs property is unoccupied most of the time and is in the believes travel corridor of the bear. Trap set 6/18, picked up 6/22. Trap was rebaited 6/20. No pictures of the bear on trail camera

Rp called to report probable yearling bear that did not look healthy, and was wondering through neighborhood midday sniffing around for food. Rp concerned that bear by itself, but Officer Kay explained that last years cubs would likely have been booted by mom at this point. Rp has had bear issues here before w/neighborhood HOA dumpster. Based on description could be same yearling, black in color bear that’s been getting into dumpsters and more in area. Dumpster has been cleaned up since last incident where keystone property management was given a warning, but still no bar across the top. Advised RP to keep CPW advised if bear returns

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set , Rehabilitation
Comments: Small cub reported in backyard initially on 8/21. DWM Gallegos attempted to catch using catch pole on 8/22 when the cub showed back up in RP’s backyard. That attempt was unsuccessful, so DWM Gallegos set a small bobcat cage trap. Cub showed back up on Sunday, 8/23, and went into trap. Cub was only about 20 pounds and was transported up to Frisco Creek Rehab Facility.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set
Comments: Bear busted out a window sometime during the night of the 21st/22nd.  RP checks his security cam footage every morning.  Bear got into the freezer and some dry and canned goods.
Sow and 2 Cubs broke into storage shed with food inside.  Ripped through wall to get in.  Trap set at 116 Aspen Village.   Dan Fellin with Pitkin County SO is property owner.   987-2222

Archuleta County SO Dispatch called stating they had received a call from the County Office that they would like an officer dispatched because a bear went through the neighbor's trash at this address. W328 visited RP and resident. W328 warned neighbor not to leave trash out.

WL281 received a call around 1:11 AM that a man was attacked by a bear. Dispatch told him that the man had no contact with the bear and he was ok. They also told him that the bear was dead. 
WL 281 called the RP, Richard Gallion, and confirmed that he was ok. He stated he had no contact with the bear, but it had come close to him. He then stated that he killed the bear and a there were two cubs up the tree still. 
Upon further questioning the RP stated that he went outside to see what his dogs were barking at. He saw his dogs near a bear, that was in a tree. He was scared his dogs were going to be attacked so he went to pull them back. As he got closer he felt like his life was in danger and he shot and killed the bear. He stated that the bear came out of the tree and died a short distance from it. 
The sow was investigated by WL281 and WL287. 
Two cubs were darted and transported to a local rehaber.
Seal number for sow: 40356

WL124: RP watches over neighbor's (absent landowner) house when they are gone. RP stated that within the past two weeks a bear broke through the screened in porch and then broke through the door into the cabin. The bear went foraged the kitchen cabinets and refrigerator  and got a food reward. Provided RP with rubber buckshot rounds.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials
Comments: Bear got into trashcan and dumped it.  RP found him sleeping in the shade in her backyard.  Gave RP a living with bears pamphlet, recommended they keep the doors and windows shut and latched etc.  Showed then how to set the trashcan up with a ratchet strap.  Gave them a business card and asked them to call me if they had any further conflicts.

The bear was injured and is likely related to a vehicle/bear collision on 9/28/2020 just west of MM 228 on US Hwy 285.  The bear was euthanized.  The bear had trauma to the back legs and the abdomen.  The bear would not move or flea when approached.

Bear was in his trashcan last night.  Recommended he use a ratchet strap to secure the lid on the can and he has already implemented that.  RP asked if it would be ok if he hazed the bear the next time it was in his backyard with a paintball gun.  I told him he could.  Recommended he keep his doors and windows on tje back of the house shut and latched.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials
Comments: RP captured a sow with 2 cubs on her video recording doorbell walking through the front yard of her cabin. She had some concerns about safety for her family. WL 261 answered her questions and informed her that he would bring up educational fliers when they returned to the cabin.

Chatfield State Park Rangers called to report a small bear hanging out in the park for the past couple days. The animal had entered populated areas, but was scared away by loud noises. It then showed up again on the afternoon of June 9, and entered the campground and crawled underneath a camper. The bear appeared very tired and not looking to leave the area, so it was immobilized and relocated to better habitat. A body condition assessment was completed, and it was determined the bear was in good health. No previous history of a bear matching this description was seen in surrounding areas. J Olson
Bear injured in ditch. Both back legs broken.
Bear poppedpartially open window (side window) out of car to get to Coca-Cola... License number SWQ 888

Bear digging in trash at RP apartment complex. WL 290 got eyes on the bear and was only able to verbally haze and haze with a warning arc of a taser. 

Unable to haze with les lethal due to the number people around. On site education was provided to approximately 12 people in the area to secure trash and scare the bear when they see it.
Yearling brown phase bear without ear tags. Tazed and hazed out of town towards the ski area.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set , Hazed , Euthanized
Comments: Bear attempted to get into occupied dwelling and has been doing so for past few weeks. Many hazing techniques including sub lethal rounds and pepper barrel utilized w no success. WL 485 handled situation including trap. Bear trapped on night of 8/9-8/10. Euthanized on 8/10. Seal # 39366

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials
Comments:
RP told me they saw a large cinnamon colored bear eating chicken feed at their residence.  The bear broke part of their fence and entered the chicken yard to get the food.  They  fired 2 shots into the ground with a .22 to get the bear to run off.  

Went to the RP's residence and asked them to remove their hummingbird feeders and suet.  Recommended they put their chicken feed in a steel drum with a snapping lid, and recommended they purchase electrified poultry netting for the chicken coop yard.  

Issued rubber buckshot.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Trap Set , Relocated , Pyrotechnics
Comments: Large bear visits every night. Bear has been  tearing down birdfeeders and getting into buckets and bags of bird feed. Bear knocks over bearproof trash can and breaks into it. Bear has gone through 2 strand electric fence and ate 7 ducks and some chickens. Issued rubber buck, advised RP to take down birdfeeders and put away feed, advised to change electric fence to 4 wire fence and keep duck/chicken feed in fenced area. Bear caught night of 7/30. RP advises that it was not the same bear that killed the ducks and chickens. RP said they have seen 3 different bears, and the one that killed the the animals was bigger. WL324 reset trap after relocating the non target bear.

RP stated that the fertilizer pilot had reported to him he had seen a bear in his sweet corn field on the NW corner of his property on 2 occasions within the past week. Pilot also reported the bear had caused damage to the field. I came out to the property and found several bear tracks and minor damage to the field. Too much of a safety hazard to run hounds in this field. Could not set a trap until the following afternoon, due to all 3 traps being in use. Sat on the field Saturday night after finding fresh sign and again on Sunday night.

Monday, 8/3 bear was pushed out into adjacent field by pickers. Mature bear, possibly with an eartag.
Cub possibly orphaned had been in Loveland for over a week. Decided to relocate .

Small bear hanging around the parking lot of Costco in gypsum.  CSP called it in.  465 inspected, bear was approximately 5 feet up in a spruce tree between the parking lot and HWY 6, so decision was made to leave it be.  Bear has been hanging in the area the last few days, not scared of people.

Bear got into his trash 3 nights in a row.  Recommended putting the trash in the garage or securing the container with a ratchet strap.  Gave him additional standard bear aware recommendations.  RP was rude to Crystal in the Salida office when she suggested he secure his trash!

WL 283 talked with the RP after setting a trap about 5 minutes away. A bear broke into her vehicle by breaking the passenger side front window. Based on the paw prints on the outside of the vehicle and the hair I found at 9685 Mohawk Trail (where WL283 set the trap) and comparing them to this RP’s vehicle I would say that it was likely the same bear that broke into both vehicles. The bear is a medium sized bear that will be a very dark brown or black colored bear.

Complaint Type: Food Source Property Damage , Sighting , Aggressive Behavior

Comments: roadkill bear.  Seal # 33732
Counter Assault furnished.

Service Provided: Advice/Phone Call , Site Inspection , Educational Materials
Comments:
On 08/03/2020 Wildlife 261 got a call that someone had called into CSP stating that there has been a bear visiting the Iron City Campground every couple night. WL 261 contacted the RP who stated that she was the camp host at a different but near by campground as was checking on the Iron City Campground every once in a while because they did not have a full time camp host for Iron City. She stated that on 07/30/2020 campers had reported seeing a large bear with ear tags (unknown color) walking threw the campground. the campers stated that the bear was not aggressive but was not bothered by humans making noise or yelling at it. The RP did not know what time the bear was seen or how often it had come back to the campground but stated that multiple campers had seen the bear.  The RP also did not know how many times the bear had gotten into campers trash at the campground but stated that there were bear boxes at the campground. The RP also stated that a new camp host would be at the campground full time starting 08/03/2020. WL 261 stated that he would mark the campground with a bear in the area sign, educated the new camp host about the bear activity, educate current campers and haze the bear if possible.  The RP stated that she had thought CPW had been informed about the incident before this, and was sorry she didn't call sooner. 

WL 261 put a bear in the area sign up in front of campground, and talked with camp host and campers. After talking to campers who were in the campground when the bear came through, they stated that the bear tried to get into the bear boxes that the campground provides to campers and was unsuccessful at getting any food and then found a cooler in an unattended campsite and got into that.

On 08/08/2020 the RP (new camp host of Iron City) called and let WL 261 know that the night before at about 8:30 PM a bear came back into camp and walked within 30 yards of a large group of campers at site 15. After yelling and and throwing sticks at the bear it finally walked away. Later that night at about 2:30 AM a bear returned to site 15 again and got into a cooler filled with ice that the campers had left out and a black container that had cooking utensils in it. WL 261 and WL 264 responded to the campground that day and spoke with the RP as well as every camp site that had occupants in the campground and educated them on the importance of using the bear boxes provided by the camp ground to store coolers and food of any kind. The sign that was dropped off at the last incident remained up at the front of the campground.

WL526 was notified of a bear in a car at the above address. Officer attempted to contact RP by phone. No answer, so officer drove to address. Contacted female subject, who said they attached a rope to the door and let the bear out.  Car doors were unlocked and food items were in the car.
Bear killed two alpacas

Complaint Type: Food Source Property Damage , Non-Food Property Damage

Comments: 325 was informed by a neighbor of residence (who had separate bear issue) that they had a bear break into a garage a couple weeks ago. 325 contacted Horton at residence, who showed him the shed where a bear broke a handle off the heavy sliding door and took trash bags down the hill. Shed door has since  been fixed and lock installed. Horton is new to area so 325 recommended various bear-proofing methods.

Mary Porter reported that she believed a bear had killed one of her domestic elk cows on 5/24/20 to the Glenwood Springs office on 5/26/20. 442 was unable to visit the site until 5/27/20. 

Upon arrival the carcass was heavily scavenged, with bear scat throughout the area. The carcass is located within a high fenced domestic elk enclosure occupied by approximately 150 additional elk cows who are preparing to calf. Mary is worried about possible future predation on the calves. 

Trap set on 5/27/20
Trap pulled on 6/1/20
Trap was unsuccessful. No further predation or sighting had occured so 442 supplied Mary Porter with a game damage packet for her alternative livestock, was instructed to call 442 immediately if bear returned, and informed of her right to defend her livestock from active predation.

End of incident at this time.

Rp reporting their neighbor (Jarad) at:
4979 Grouse Court
Evergreen, CO
80439

Jarad is the tenant. 2 other people recently started staying there but these trash incidents happened with Jarad.

Left flier on porch and was called by Martin.  He said they will get the trash situation under control.  I explained ways to mitigate the situation and that they could recieve a citation if they don't get their trash situation under control.
